This was the best experience ever, we got collected at our hostel and went to a local market, where our guide explained the various stalls and traditions, we then went to the farm, it was beautiful, green and natural, we chilled with coffee and cake before been guided around the farm to pick our veg for the cookery course. The guide explained the about the herbs and vegtables (organic and natural).. Then the cooking started it was amazing, informative and tasty, our chef was so friendly, fun and knew exactly what he was talking about, the food and atmosphere was amazing. If you want a fun packed day and when you leave to feel like a mini chef then this place is recommended, it's in the heart of the country side, with people who know good food and know how to cook it, you even get a recipe book and apron, just brilliant

Well worth doing!. My whole family did the cooking class, even my 11 year old son enjoyed it. To be cooking in the middle of their organic farm was just beautiful, so much nicer than in a kitchen. The food was amazing and the people were too! Such good value and it was really nice to visit the local markets as well, great experience well worth doing!

A great day. This was going to be a cookery day, but the 'recipe' turned out to be much more intriguing than expected. It began with an hours journey through forest and villages just waking for the day ahead. Then followed a walk around a village market, high up in the hills. Villagers busily collected and bargained for their goods; vegetables, chicken and fruit. All the spices we saw were identified and explained for the next part of the day. For the first time since coming to Bali, I felt as if I was experiencing the real Bali.The farm was set in an organic garden of spices, papaya, banana and many other fruit growing beside mandarins, coffee and lemongrass. We picked our cooking ingredients as we walked and then made our way to the pavilion where tables were set out to welcome us, each with its own apron, cookery book and place setting.Several enjoyable hours later we had learnt how to make the all important basic paste for Balinese cooking, and had produced with lots of help from the excellent chefs, three main courses and chicken satay. All of this was eaten with great pleasure and satisfaction. We had fun, great food, learnt much about Balinese food and met delightful people. A great day, don't miss this experience!

Educational and Tasty!. My mum and I had a look at the cooking classes on offer in Ubud and initially picked this class as it was great value (35USD) and was held on the farm rather than in a hotel restaurant. We didn't really know what to expect but were really impressed by this trip and had a great day.We were picked up from our hotel (15 minutes outside Ubud) at 7am and driven towards the mountains to a local village market close to the farm. Our driver took us round, explaining all the local foods and some of the traditions involved with cooking and eating. We were the only tourists there but everyone was friendly and made us feel welcome.The cooking school is an open-air pavilion set in the middle of a small organic farm. All the people working there are part of an extended family from the local village and were extremely hospitable and knowledgable. The level of English instruction was excellent, the teachers very patient and the cookbook and apron we got to take away were a lovely gesture.We started with a tour round the farm, looking at all the different fruit, veggies and spices grown there. Everything is grown organically and you got to pick the veggies that we were going to use later for the class.There were eight of us taking the class, so we were split into two teams of four and shared the cooking around two stoves. We were shown how to produce the spice paste base used in Balinese cooking and produced four meat and veggie dishes over the course of the morning, with giant banana fritters to finish. We were done around 3.00pm, so as well as being a really fun day, having transport to the hotel and a massive feed, we felt this was excellent value for money.

Delicious and simple Balinese cooking in the 'kampung'!. "Real food by Real farmer in the Real village community!" - that was the tagline on the back of Wayan's (one of the owners) T-shirt when he picked us up for our cooking 'day'! We had tasted a number of delicious Balinese dishes during our stay, and we couldn't wait to learn about the local spice mixes and cooking techniques :)Wayan took us to a large fresh food and flower wholesale market before driving into the quiet town of Taro. Balinese Farm Cooking & Organic Farm is located on a beautiful and unspoilt piece of land close to where the local villagers live. The land belongs to one of the chefs' family and is truly a community project - a source of sustainable income for the villagers, and an enjoyable way for tourists to experience an important part of the Balinese lifestyle... the food!!It's all in the family as Wayan's brother and the cute lady chef du jour (Ketut) took us foraging for edible greens around the farm and natural surrounds. We then prepared four popular Balinese dishes and one dessert over the next 2 hours. A book of Balinese recipes and our trusty black/white apron were not the only items we took away with us, as we felt so welcomed by Wayan and his team :) It was such a lovely experience for us and we would highly recommend it!

Great fun and delicious!. My husband and I were lucky enough to sign up for a Market Tour and Cooking Class through Casa Luna. What fun! We really enjoyed the market tour and our tour guide was so knowledgeable, plus there are some really awesome things for sale (we even went back later to check it out on our own). It's huge! You could easily spend a full afternoon browsing all the booths, but I'm happy that we had a guide to walk us through it and explain the different types of produce and variety of items.Next up was the actual cooking portion. It was so informative and they shared all the recipes, and we got hands-on experience cooking and chopping and making every dish. We were taught about the flavors, ingredients, and techniques. We made good friends with our group (they were very social, which made it so fun!) and at the end we enjoy a delicious (and filling!) meal!The only downside was the there wasn't A/C (it was in a shaded area though), and especially with the woks it got VERY warm. But there was plenty of cool hibiscus tea to drink to cool off - yum! At some points I got a little tired, so I just sat on the couch and enjoyed the afternoon. Participating in the cooking aspect of the class was entirely voluntary, so don't shy away if you aren't a big cooker (but are a big eater like me!).We would definitely take this tour and class again when we come back to Bali, as we greatly enjoyed it. I recommend it to anyone who likes shopping, cooking, or learning about cuisine.

Excellent cultural and culinary experience!. Such a fantastic experience on the Thursday market tour and homestyle cooking class! This tour was not only a cooking lesson, but a lesson in Balinese culture in general, especially pertaining to family life, gender roles, and spiritual practices. Our tour guides were friendly and informative, with lots of opportunities for questions. The market tour certainly enabled us to see things we wouldn't have otherwise been exposed to. The cooking lesson included so many dishes, and provided us with a recipe book which will allow us to make the dishes at home. Fantastic time

Very good class, the host was wonderfull. The cooking class was great, we all enjoyed it! we went through the booklet of the what we were going to be cooking followed by passing some of the ingredients around the table and discussing what we could replace them with if that ingredient was not available at home. then the demonstrations started, we were all broken off into groups to prepare the ingredients and all took turns at cooking it/! the food was amazing. we all learnt lots. I would highly recommend. I would also recommend paying when you get there.

Absolutely brilliant day. We managed to book two places in a Friday morning cooking school at the last minute, and we are so pleased we did! Upon arrival at the school, we were meet with a wonderful teacher (who was later joined by another teacher) and iced hibiscus tea which the teacher later demonstrated how to make. The class was fun, engaging and informative, and we were taught the stories of the food we cooked. It was lovely to prepare and share the meal as a communal activity, rather then individually or as a couple. Although I am vegetarian, I was able to enjoy all the food with the exception of the chicken satay (although there was delicious Tempeh satay).Now whenever we prepare Balinese food we reminisce about our holiday and at the cooking school. It is a wonderful memory to have and we will certainly attend another class when we next visit Bali. Since attending the class, we have prepared the recipes we learn multiple times, in particular the pickled carrot and cucumber which we eat weekly, and nasi gorang. Upon leaving, we purchase Janet's book "Fragrant Rice", which woke recipes into her personal story about life in Bali and the island rich history and culture. Highly recommend the book!

Indonesian cooking class . Had a wonderful time learning to cook some basic and well known Indonesian dishes. Our teaches was so friendly and a great teacher. We got to eat the delicious food we cook as a group at the end of the class. The size of the class was the only trouble. I think we were simply unlucky to have booked on the same day as two large families with small children, who were unfortunately uninterested in cooking. If you are thinking of bringing small children I can guaranty that the teaches are very welcome and great with children. We did get lost on our way to the class, because we went to Casa Luna restaurant instead of the Honeymoon guest house, so my tip is to make sure you know where to go before the class! If you are thinking of taking a cooking class in Bali them I would definitely recommend Casa Luna.

Fun, friendly class. We really enjoyed this class, was easily one of the best activities in Ubud. The teacher is very friendly and funny. You start with a introduction to Balinese ingredients and then move onto to a hands in demonstration. We went through 5/6 classic Balinese dishes and got to eat them all at the end! I would definitely recommend this. Only slight negative was I felt the group size was a little too big.

Fun and informative. Started with interesting tour of market, learnt a little more about Balinese culture and about food and spices they use. Cooked a two curries and some salads, very tasty and not too full on. Great experience.

Don’t get what you pay for - no feast…. Two small pieces of Murtabak, two tastes of Balinese sweets, a plate of Baba Guling and a few pieces of fresh fruit washed down with a bottle of cold tea does not a ‘feast’ make as advertised on the website for this Night Market tour. Quote from Casluna website “ this is followed by an open-air feast of home-cooked specialties, from braised chicken to marinated satay, spicy greens and grilled seafood.. “Where was the home cooked specialities - braised chicken, marinated satay, spicy greens or grilled seafood?Our guide was friendly and informative, and we could have as much Baba Guling as we wanted to eat however we came on this tour to learn about and taste the various foods of the night market not hog into Baba Guling (which was not tender and melt in your mouth as it should be) a national dish that is well known and available in many restaurants. Janet after reading your responses to other negative reviews for this tour I don’t think that you get that people aren’t complaining about the market, or eating at the market - it’s about not getting value for what was advertised - especially after the buildup as to the range and quality of Bali’s #1 Night Market we got from our guide along the way. I estimate that for 5 people - who paid around $210 AUD we consumed about $12 worth of food! Yes I understand you have to pay the driver - say half a day $25!  I would have been happier to pay just for the guide and information for less money.Bottom line it was not worth the money by a long shot. We had lunch including wine at the #1 Restaurant in Ubud on Trip Advisor for less. I would only recommend this tour is good value for a person on their own - after that just get a driver to take you to the Gianyar Night Market.

participationand recipes to repeat at home. The Thursday cooking school began with a market tour where increased knowledge about fruit and vegetables and knives and spices was on the curriculum. Afterwards some nice hibiscus tea was had while we learnt how to make our own. We also had tastings of various Balanese dishes. Next the cuttung and grinding of ingreadients kept us busy and informed. The guy taking the class was engaging, nclusive and very knowledable. The food at the nd was delicious and we were able to take the recipes home. A great choice for $40 Aus

Great morning cooking delicious food!. We all enjoyed our morning learning to cook Balinese favourites. The session was a good mix of demonstration and hands on opportunity. Our instructor, Oleg (I hope I've got his name right!), was very interesting, enthusiastic and good at trying to help everyone. We enjoyed eating the food at the end of the session and the hibiscus ice tea available throughout the session was delicious too. We were given detailed recipes and notes about the ingredients and have now successfully recreated some of the recipes at home.

Fantastic cooking class with GREAT teacher!. I took the vegan food as medicine class; I loved it even though I'm a meat eater. we made a delicious and healthy feast that was literally the best Balinese food I had in Bali! The teacher yude ("you day") is funny, kind, clear and encouraging -- id gladly take more of her cooking classes from her. Yude, thank you for making my time at Honeymoon Guesthouse such a joy! There are lots and lots of cooking classes in Bali but I've heard from any that this one is the best -- I believe it! Excited to make these recipes when I get home to the USA.

Excellent, Interesting, Tasty, Well run, Beautiful setting. In this part of the world there are a lot of cooking classes. This is a cooking experience and quite educational. Janet really knew her stuff having lived in Bali for many many years and having a Balinese family so it was not a case of a westerner thinking they knew Balinese food. The setting was tranquil and beautiful with lots of lovely staff to help you. It started with an interesting and useful demonstration on all the local spices (who knew there were that many types of turmeric or ginger!) followed by us all preparing and then taking turns cooking. It was great to learn how the Balinese use these foods for medicinal purposes as well as listening to various local tales. The class was 15 in size and we all had a chance to do something - we even had a couple of MKR celebrities drop in! This was a Monday morning fish class and lasted from about 0930 to roughly 2pm. Not quite the cooking class where you prepare everything and cook everything just for yourself, rather this was more communal , more the Balinese way, but no less an experience and still very interactive. We prepared starters, 2 different fish dishes, 2 salads and some banana wrapped morsels. Professionally run, friendly, high quality and the results were so tasty. A useful guide with all the recipes etc were provided at the beginning.I am no cook whilst my wife and daughter are great cooks, but we all came out of it enthused (and full).

Great learning and cooking experience. I would recommend this cooking school. Our instructor was just wonderful and very entertaining. The class is taught in an open area with a covered top. You get an opportunity to cook a variety of local dishes and then get to eat your meal you helped to cook.

A fun way to learn some lovely new recipes . This was a really fun way to spend a morning. We did the Friday beginners class and our instructor was Balinese, chatty, hilarious and so full of joy, she really cracked us up. The ingredients were fresh and the dishes delicious. An inspiring intro to Balinese cooking.

Great teacher, little bit hands off for skilled cooks. The cooking school was great with a awesome selection of dishes in the traditional range of Balinese food. I chose to do the Wednesday cooking class due to conflicting schedules, but was disappointed to not have individual cooking stations for the price and such a large class of mostly disinterested participants. Weird doing a cooking class with so many people that were not really interested in participating and were obviously roped into it by keen family members. Absolutely loved the chef teaching and would recommend her to anyone wanting to try to learn the art of Balinese cooking. Sadly I feel having so many people in the group so disinterested in cooking took away from the joy of a cooking class which I felt Yude tried her hardest to alleviate, with mixed results. I personally thought she was an absolute riot and loved her stories and sense of humour, but several of the participants missed the point so many times it was painful to watch (this is their fault and not hers). Overall I thought it was a great beginner's class which for me was a small problem, wanting to spend less time identifying Galangal (something I see everyday) and more time on the finer techniques of Balinese traditional cooking. Also made it quite uncomfortable to eat surrounded by people that didn't even wash their hands once and yet still prepared food I put in my mouth. Maybe a tip for future classes is mandatory hand washing before touching food. Makes chefs like me a little less uneasy.Despite the issues, would definitely recommend if only for a awesome face to face with Chef Yude and her helpers who were my highlight of the class.Thank you Janet, Yude and team!Andrew

Wonderful fun!. The cooking classes are very interesting and lively. The instructors are full of personality and interesting anecdotes on life and cooking in Bali. Much more than just a lesson on how to cook. The service was excellent and the lessons were very enjoyable. More importantly the food tasted great and the ingredients were fresh. Overall a very enjoyable and professional experience. I would highly recommend.

Wonderful Experience. Wonderful cooking class! Learned a lot about preparation, spices,vegetables and Indonesian traditional dishes. Instructor was very entertaining. Wish we could have taken home our aprons! But we did go home with recipes and had a lovely lunch we prepared ourselves. Highly recommended.

Seeking a truly wonderful cooking school?. One of the best classes I have attended. Balinese cooking with excellent notes, properly written (not always the case in Bali!) Delicious food, great tips and hands on experiences, set in lovely tropical gardens. Honeymoon Guesthouses offer these classes as part of their packages as well or simply book online or at their reception desk. Various classes run throughout the week - just choose whatever class takes your fancy!

Food as Medicine Vegetarian Class. Janet was patient attentive and inspiring. It was a wonderful class and an experience I will repeat. I love the Balinese salad Urab. We made a couple of versions and they were the best I have tasted.

Great cooking class which was enjoyable,informative and the food was delicious.. This was a great cooking class in a beautiful setting. The class included information about all the ingredients, cooking demonstrations , hands on participation and finally, eating the delicious food. I would love to return for another class. The class was the right size and there was opportunities to participate in the food preparation and all questions were answered by the lovely staff. A great experience from start to finish. It is a good idea to book early as the classes fill really quickly.

Take home cooking souvenior. This was a great way to take home a taste of Bali. Catering to all skill levels this lesson is as hands on or off as you want it to be. Cutting , dicing grinding and above all laughing and then enjoying the food you have all prepared was great. We had 12 in all from Europe, Australia and New Zealand . Oleg was a good instructor supported by a small team of very helpful staff. The history of the food we were preparing was explained, items that can be substituted , those that cannot as a well as a take away copy of the recipies we prepared.Be sure to look into a transfer package if considering this school as we saved a bundle on other participants who arranged independent travel. Highly recommend

Awesome way to learn more about Bali culture. I had the fortune of booking into the cooking class that was conducted by Hanet herself. Her passion for her island home and its food came through in this class. The food was "enak" and the staff were so friendly and helpful. A must do while visiting Bali.
a great time. I really enjoyed this especially how we learnt all about the different herbs and spices and their medicinal as well as culinary uses. Very friendly staff, a great experience

Cooking lesson . The class Janet taught was called Food is Medicine. It was amazing. We learned about each ingredient and then cooked together and enjoyed our dishes together!! She's cool, funny, and full of stories of old Bali!!

What a great experience!!. This is the second time I have participated in a cooking class at Casa Luna Cooking School and it was every bit as good as the first time (more so this time as I did it with my husband as well). You couldn't fault our instructors - they were both personable and knowledgeable and were very patient with us amateurs...We learnt to cook two of our favourite dishes from Indus - the corn fritters and gado gado and if we are lucky we will be able to recreate them for family and friends back home. Best of all, at the end of the class we got to feast on the fruits of our labour - best meal I have had during this trip, even if I do say so myself...I would highly recommend this cooking class to anyone visiting beautiful Ubud....
Fabulous experience. My husband and I attended the cooking school for the duck class and had a fabulous time. A great experience if you're in Ubud.

A must do when visiting Ubud.. This was a great activity to do to explore more of the local culture especially the visit to the food market which was really interesting. This was one of the more expensive cooking class options but well worth the price for all that was included, especially the guide and our cooking instructors who were extremely friendly, funny and really made the morning worth it. Would highly recommend this.

Fantastic tour of the night market - Highlight of our trip!. We booked the night market tour ahead of time and paid around £20 each. They run the tour on Thursday and Friday evenings. We met at Casa Luna restaurant in Ubud around 5.30pm with the tour kicking off at 6pm. They usually require a minimum of 4 people - my husband and I got really lucky and joined with a wonderful couple from Bolivia/Germany which made our trip all the more special. We were driven 20 minutes from Ubud to Gianyar which is where the district night market is located. We had an amazing guide who spoke incredible English and explained the customs and delicacies of the food there. We were shown as a group around the interesting stalls and stands selling food, flowers, fruit and clothes, sampling dishes as we went, with lots of opportunities to ask questions. Can't speak more highly of our guide or the kind local people who made us feel so welcome. The tour finished with a fantastic meal at a particularly good stand where a range of Indonesian dishes were washed down with some lovely iced tea. If you are used to a mild Western palate you will probably find the food quite spicy - enjoy! You will rarely find more flavour some treats on your trip. Thank you for an amazing time!

Never again. My sister and I did the cooking class on Tuesday 31st we must of been very unlucky that day. First of all we had 5 minutes notice for our transfer pick up to the class (6:55am call to be ready and leave by 7am!) we left at 7:15 but we arrived 35min late to the class which still doesn't add up, we should of been picked up early and a msg should of been left at reception the night before telling us what time to be ready!When we got there we went to the food market and did a quick tour to catch up with the class the guide was very nice and When we got back to Casa Luna I asked one of the male cooks if he knew that my sister can't eat seafood.. He didn't so he looked at our paper work then wrote something down and said two beef? I said yes and thought the problem was fixed. I realize these two mistakes were done by the travel agent and transfer company and not your class but the last straw for that day was the way we were spoken to in this class.When we first started cooking the main lady cooking asked why we were late we told her and she went back to the demonstration, about 1 hr later some food was past around and the lady noticed everyone had some but my sister. She asked her why and my sister explained because she can't eat seafood and we're sorry about the miscommunication (I forgot that I had told one of the staff members in the beginning really wish I told her that!)She said oh no if she knew she could of done something about it.Then we moved on to the next step in the class.. More food was past around my sister didn't eat it again and the lady started the conversation again "if I knew I could of done something but you didn't tell me" I stepped in and said "yes we realize this wasn't your mistake and we'll talk about it after the class" she agree and said yes I need more information later.10 or so minutes later she came over and said "I don't like your tour guide she's very rude to me" the worst bit was she kept doing this in front of everyone in the class making it very uncomfortable and awkward that was the last straw for me and we walked out. The tour guide/driver was from the included transfer in the class meaning it had nothing to do with us! She should of sorted it out with the tour guide one on one or told her boss so she could sort it out with the other company.. NOT come over to us (the customers) and repeatedly tell us about her problem with the tour guide infront of everyone.It takes a lot for me to complain and I've never walked out of anything before in my life.. It ruined our day. So disappointed how this was handled.Ps anyone doing this class that can't eat seafood best not to do the class because using beef or chicken instead still wouldn't be enough there's shrimp paste, fish sauce and cut up eel in everything. If we where told this to beginning with we would of never booked it and this would of never happened. I suggest morning information in the ads next time.

Cooking demonstration, Not cooking class. This is a cooking demonstration. We chopped garlic. We booked 2 days running. Same same no different. I would suggest you eat nasi champur at casa luna restaurant, google recipies and save yourself 40 dollars. Go to Paon cooking school ubud.It is an excellent hands on cooking school.

A M A Z I N G. We had a great day today exploring the markets first of all with a guided tour. It was so interesting to understand a little bit more about the traditional foods and why they use them. We then walked down to the honeymoon villa where all the cooking took place. The food was all so fresh and the herbs and spices smelt amazing. You could be as little involved as you wanted, but we had a great time chopping and slicing then using the mortar and pestle to grind all the herbs into the paste. Everyone was so lovely and friendly and had a great sense of humour. After all the cooking was done we got to sit down and enjoy it all, it was delicious ! I would HIGHLY recommend this class !
Delicious!!! . Was fantastic!!! The tips on how to cook yummy food were plentiful and it was completely delicious. You get to take the recipes home too!! Yuuuum!!!

Cooking up a storm. Our Casa Luna cooking class was great. Walk around the market and through the main street was memorable. We had morning tea prior to the cook and our guide was very funny and helpful. We started with Hibiscus tea which was very refreshing followed by some tasty morsels of Indonesian food.The cooking class was held by an Aussie woman who has lived in Bali for many years and she was very informative. The prep, cook and eat of all of our food was great. We have come home loving Indonesian Food and can't wait til we can try to replicate at home. I can highly recommend this activity

Interactive, hands on cooking experience!. Personally enjoyed this cooking experience alot. The local chef was chatty, fun yet very knowledgable. He introduced us to all the local herbs, ingredients and also the balinese cooking utensils prior to the commencement of the cooking class. He walk us through the recipe book and shared with us the daily life being a balinese. Very insightful. We had the opportunity to participate in the cooking. Cooking various dishes using different types of balinese utensils were quite an interesting experience. We were served with the food cooked from the cooking class. Quite a good activity in Ubud.Price wise: For the food that we cooked, personally don't think is cheap. However, worth to give it a go if you are a first timer in Ubud.

What a treat!. 10 of us enjoyed the Saturday class run by the friendly informative Obed. We learnt about herbs and spices by touch and smell and then sliced and pounded and created two delicious curries, 3 salads, rice and tempeh which we could eat as much as we liked. As an average cook in my sixties I learnt lots of tips which I will put into practice. This was a vegetarian/ vegan class. We had read Janet's book Fragrant Rice beforehand which enhanced our class as well as our time in Ubud
Good learning . Fantastic experience and very cheerful and professional team. Fun approach to the Balinese gastronomy with very clear instructions to bring back home with you.

Beautiful life changing cooking class from fantastic chef Janet. This was the absolute highlight of our trip to Ubud.Janet taught us a lot about the benefits of certain foods that has changed the way we look at them forever.And no spoonful of sugar needed to make the medecine go down as everything was so yummie.We ate the complete plate of tempeh sambal goreng even before it had a chance to touch the table (forgive us gluttons!).We definitely will change our menu and we will use the advice to our advantage and we will be certainly back next year for new inspiration from this very special lady chef.My compliments!!!(Also as a bonus you will be given the most yummie coconut ice cream ever made on the planet, and I know because I have been around in my work for KLM!)

Lovely way to learn and eat great food. 6 of us were on the Monday cookery class - this was fish based. They have a different type of food for each day. Chopping spices, grinding by hand and then demonstration cooking. Our chef was delightful and made everyone feel comfortable.Lunch was what we had made - delicious.Around A$40 for a 2.5 hour activity. Highly recommended and based in Honeymoon guesthouses....take a towel and use their small pool afterwards.

vegetarian cooking class. Janet was away so we had a local lady presenting and she was wonderful :) Learned so much about daily eating life in Bali! Plus we all got tired arms from all the mortar and pestle work...three of us went together, another 8 attended - nice to meet people from around the world and make the lunch together. Overall very clean, and very fresh food - we did the vegetarian Saturday morning class, and 'food as medicine' was covered. I would recommend this particular class

More demonstration than cooking class. As previous reviewers have mentioned, this is more of a cooking demonstration than a hands on class. We had 11 in our group, which I thought was still too large, even though it sounds as if they have recently tried to cap class numbers at around 12.The recipe booklet provided is clear and well presented, however the class itself was not quite what I was expecting. I learnt some interesting tips on various ingredients and methods in general, but don't feel like I actually learnt how to make some the dishes made in the class, since most of the prep and cooking were done by the staff. The food did taste great, and our instructor was very enthusiastic, entertaining and experienced (although I do understand how some people have found her jokes and banter a little off- she is definitely a 'personality'!) All in all, an interesting experience, but maybe not the best value for money.

Good vegetarian cooking class, not much on food as medicine . I had read Janet's book Fragrant Rice so was keen to attend one of her cooking classes. I chose to attend the Saturday Food as Medicine cooking class as I wanted to learn more about medicinal properties of Balinese cooking as well as learning how to cook Balinese food. I'm a naturopath/herbalist and learning more about food as medicine interests me. The class started with information about the different herbs and spices used in Balinese cooking. There was very little information on medicinal properties of the herbs and spices, nor what illnesses Balinese people used the herbs and spices for. This was disappointing. Maybe the class needs to be renamed Vegetarian Cooking Class. We got to handle, smell and taste most of the herbs and spices in the food that was prepared. The plus side was we did make some very tasty vegetarian food. Even my non-vegetarian husband agreed the food was tasty and filling. The vegetarian food we prepared will be added to our home cooking. Unlike other cooking classes I've attended everything was done in a group rather than individually. Watching someone else cook in a wok or mix ingredients into a particular meal doesn't really teach you how to cook in a wok or prepare that meal. I prefer a cooking class that is more hands on. The teacher was funny and informative. The class was a lot of fun. I was happy with the hygiene at the cooking school.

Visit to food market & cooking lessons followed by a Balinese feast.. We met at the restaurant from where we visited the food market with the tour leader. Then on to the cooking school, which was really good. We then enjoyed the delicious feast that we had cooked with thirst-quenching hybiscus punch. I thoroughly recommend it to people who like to cook & enjoy eating Balinese food.

Great fun, worth the early morning start from Seminyak!. The market tour starts at 8:00am so be prepared for an early start if you are staying out of Ubud. The guide was friendly, engaging and had a great sense of humour. The tour of the local market was just as you would expect - full of colour, interesting smells and lots of activity. As the market was 'changing' from a food market to a tourist market, which it does around 10:00am every day, we headed back to the cooking school for a taste of the local breakfast delights and a lesson in how to make hibiscus tea. Then the 'work' started. Our chef had a wonderful personality, was a great story-teller also with a good sense of humour. We got to chop and prepare vegetables and condiments for 8 dishes we ended up making, and then eating for lunch. A very enjoyable experience, that we were able to share with people from around the globe. I can't wait to try out some of the recipes at home. I recommend you review the menu before selecting your class, as it varies each day of the week.

Disappointed but good food. Perhaps I didn't read through the material well enough but I was under the impression that Janet was going to host the cooking class. I agree with the review below, I must have attended the day after this group. While the instructor is clearly skilled and highly knowledgeable her presentation was lacking. Constant jokes felt like we were her audience requiring feedback. I felt irritated by the constant laughing and jokes. I hesitated writing this because clearly she is a nice person, but I want others to know what to expect so you might explore another option that will better meet your expectations. As a sidenote, the restroom I used did not have hand soap which was troubling knowing we were going to be handling the food. They did find some soap once I asked for some. Overall, seems the growth of this groups businesses, may have contributed to a lack of attention to detail. This feedback also comes from eating lunch at Casa Luna the day prior and experiencing very mediocre service by unmotivated servers. However I echo the same comment as above, the food was good there also.

A very tasty experience. They pick you up in the morning, drive you to this nice place and you start to learn under the guidance of a kind, energic, smiling and very experienced lady. I enjoyed the company, the hours spent to learn and the excellent lunch we had at the end of all this. It's worth trying.

Good but too much talking. This was the second time we did a cooking school at Casa Luna. Because of Galungan ceremonies we couldn't do the class we wanted to but did the chicken curry class. We were grateful that a vegetarian meal was cooked with tempe curry and also a delicious tofu fritter.We felt the class was too big and was overbooked as we had 16 people and thought it was limited to 12 or 13 usually.We had the same cooking instructor as 2 years ago and we felt there was just a little too much talking and jokes and demonstrations of childbirth and while this didnt bother us it may have caused offense to some. I guess having travelled in Indonesia extensively and having done tertiary studies in Indonesian culture and language we do understand the culture but we felt uncomfortable about the discussions on caste from the instructor. Mainly because she stated how she was a high caste and the owner was low caste. This made me feel a bit uneasy.The food was great and the vibe was good with people from many different countries in the class. We do like to hear a good story, however the dialogue was a bit tedious and a bit too comedic at times.

Wonderful experience during our honeymoon. Very impressed and hope to visit one of their cooking classes again in the future, when on Bali. It was very professional, fun and inspiring. Great for people who like to cook or just want to learn more about the balinese and indonesian food culture. A perfect way to spend an afternoon with your partner or friend.
Loved Casa Luna Cooking Classes. Wonderful fun and very interesting cooking classes with a lovely instructor, Yude, culminating in delicious lunch. Loved it. Went to three classes.

An enjoyable morning!. A good way to spend a few hours - we enjoyed the market tour and getting to know the ingredients and waking through with the locals. The cooking instructor was a lovely and enthusiastic lady who on the spot was able to adapt to me, being the only vegan in the group while still meeting the rest of the groups needs. Thank you very much casa Luna!

Probably the best thing we did on this trip to Bali. Starting with a trip to the local market you will and I mean will find the smell horendous and they do warn you of that but that is the only bad thing you learn about their way of cooking and ingredients and get tot buy whilst there, I'm sure you aren't pauing local pri but you aren't really getting ripped off either if you compare to your home prices. Then back to casa Luna to start cooking, what can I say food food food. They serve a wonderful local style breakfast and then you go on to make lunch we did Nasi Champur everything from scratch of course and it was delicious can't wait to go back and do the smoked duck Sunday evening. It's hands on so get involved and have fun.

Lovely staff, great tour & comprehensive menu. The tour started at the Casa Luna restaurant and from there we were taken to the Ubud Market. The guide was knowledgeable, funny and had excellent English. We were introduced to many local foods and crafts. From there we were taken to Honeymoon 2 where we were served Hibiscus tea and snacks from the market, which were introduced by our hilarious and friendly teacher, Udeh. The class had a good balance of preparing, cooking and eating. The menu gave us a comprehensive view of the main foods and food practices of Bali which was what we came for. The group size was manageable and we could all see what was happening.Very enjoyable morning.

Fun cooking class!. This was a great cooking class! We took the Christmas day lunch hocking class. Oer chef taught us about local ingredients and techniques for making tasty Balinese dishes. And she was very engaging and funny! I'd highly recommend this for a fun activity.

Fun experience. Interesting market visit and the class instructor Yude, was a very happy balinese lady who made the class enjoyable with her stories and jokes throughout. Enjoyed the food we learnt to cook such as the chicken curry & eggplant. The sago pudding looks ordinary but tasted really good especially when served with vanilla ice-cream! one of the must-do if you are heading to Ubud for a taste of delicious & authentic balinese food.

Enthusiastic teacher. Thank you Oleg for any enjoyable morning in your cooking class. Apart from learning some good tips about how to prepare Indonesian food, it was the best Indonesian dining experience while in Ubud. I also enjoyed Oleg's passion and enthusiasm for Bali - very nice to hear the reasons he loves the lifestyle in his native country and chooses to reside here in preference to anywhere else. We did the vegetarian cooking class - simply terrific

One of the highlights!. This was one of the best experiences ive had in Bali so far. I took the vegetarian class there and truly loved it. It has inspired me too cook and given me an even greater appreciation for Balinese cuisine. I recommend that you do this! It is a must!

Worth the time!. We started with the trip to the market where we were introduced to the foods and how they were used. They also gave us some guidelines to prices which was helpful. Then we went to a very beautiful facility- where instruction took place & we were given hibiscus tea and a couple snacks before we started. We learned a great deal about the food, culture and Indonesian cooking. Definitely worth the money and the time. Really, it was a highlight of this part of our trip.

A good introduction to Balinese food. We did the vegetarian class, learnt a lot about vegetables and spices. The cooking part is not very hands on - you get to chop and slice. The food was beautiful and the teacher entertaining.

Preparing and sharing food best way to experience Bali. Learnt so much about Balinese cooking, and life, during this five hour cooking class. We were taken on a tour of the food market first to learn about ingredients, then we chopped, stirred and finally savoured while our cheerful instructor gave gentle life lessons without even realising.

so much fun. We took a veggie cooking class and market tour with casa luna. It was so much fun. The food was amazing, the colors were amazing, the other people were fun and we can't wait to head home and "try" to copy it all!

Vegetarian Cooking class a winner!. Really enjoyed this cooking class. I did the Saturday morning vegetarian cooking class with my Mum, brother and sister in law. We instantly liked the lady that took the class who was really easy to listen to. She spoke good English and had a very happy and vibrant nature. She made jokes and told short stories about her life and her love for cooking which she learnt from her mother and grandmother before her. She had an extremely good knowledge of the types of ingredients that are and aren’t available to us in Australia and offered substitutes. I will definitely be giving the recipes a go at home. The food was out of this world!! Would definitely recommend this class to vegetarians but also to meat eaters that would like to try something new. The food was definitely not lacking in flavour. Next time I come to Bali I would be keen to try the market tour. Thanks Casa Luna we all enjoyed it, even my brother who is not overly keen on cooking. He was glad we convinced him to come. Thankyou and see you next time!

Fanastic day. We did the Thursday cooking class which included the market tour. We met at Casa Luna at 8am and left from there on foot to the Ubud Market. We had visited the market before however we saw it through completely new eyes with our Casa Luna guide who introduced us to the local ingredients and delicacies. From here we walked back to Jl Bisma to Honeymoon Cottages where the cook school is held. When we arrived cold drinks, fresh fruit and morning tea was served to us. There were 11 of us who had travelled from Bali to the course and hailed from all over the world. We all chopped ingredients on wooden boards with Balinese knives then the lovely teacher and her assistant magically combine all of the ingredients into the most divine dishes. There were about 6 dishes in total. We sat at long table and enjoy a leisurely lunch together, while dessert was prepared for us. This class was the highlight of our holiday, lovely people, excellent personable and humorous tutors and divine food. We highly recommend Casa Luna Cooking School.

More of a demonstration than a hands on cooking class but most enjoyable. I have participated in numerous cooking classes in different Asian countries over the years, in some classes everyone cooks their own entire dish and others they help to create one communal dish, which is what this class is.The teacher is a very funny lady, her English is good and the class is informative.From what I could tell, everyone seemed to be enjoying the class as much as me.The end product was delicious too.The class is run in Honeymoon Guest house 2, I was staying there which made it a no-brainer for me to choose this class and I didn't regret it.

Overpriced and Underwhelmed. I read 206susan Melbourne's review from May with dismay.We had the exact same experience not 2 weeks ago, on 1st October 2015. Nothing has changed!This tour is extremely overpriced. We were a family of 4 (12 and 15 y.o. daughters) therefore it was AU$160 or thereabouts. Can you image how much food that would buy at a Balanese market?!? "just gouging" is how my husband described it afterwards - we were both livid! The other problem was that the amount of insight gained from our guide on Thursday 1st October was minimal. We were a group of 10 and he was unable to contain the group as a cohesive group and impart much knowledge at all.This tour needs serious review.I don't appreciate being recommended it by our villa owner and it falling so far short of expectations.I am reliving my dissapointment with it as I write this when I had resolved to just "put up and shut up", pay the money and wipe it from my memory.I owe it to other "punters" to let them know too.Don't waste your money!The feedback seems to fall onto deaf ears.

Great class!. Our teacher was great! I took the duck course and it was a lot of fun. Not sure I will do this recipe at home though, it takes about 50 ingredients and takes forever to prepare but it was fun and the food was DELICIOUS!!!!!!! I had duck later in the week in a restaurant and even though it was supposed to be a restaurant specializing in duck, it was nothing compared to the duck we made in the class! Our duck was 10 times better. So was the rice and other dishes. It was fine dining at its best! I strongly recommend this course.

Cooking and Balinese Food Culture. We attended 2 cooking classes at this school, the Smoked Duck and the Fish Curry. Both were very good, with excellent and entertaining teachers.Our favorite was the smoked duck class with Oleg. Only 4 people in the class, including our teenage daughterOleg taught us about the place of food in Balinese culture and carefully took us through the smoked duck recipe as well as ceremonial yellow rice and several side dishes.The meal was a delight to the senses.If you are interested in food and in Ubud on a Sunday take this class, a lovely way to spend the evening.One of the best meals I have had any whereOur daughter also loved the class and the food

Great value, lovely setting. My partner and I did this cooking class on our last day in Ubud. Although each person doesn't individually make dishes, so might not suit avid cooks, I found it really fun and it gave an overview of Indonesian cooking in a relaxed way. It was a really nice thing to do to hang out with some other travellers and learn about local ingredients. I thought it was good value for a half day course, with lunch at the end. The teacher was lovely and the setting was nice too.

A great way to understand Balinese food. We did the Tuesday vegetarian class, staring with a market visit. Oleg gave us so much information about produce, quality and prices, so I feel that next time we come to Ubud we will be much more confident shopping for food.The actual class was given by Yude - so passionate about her Balinese food culture. Although there were about 15 in the class, it was very well organised and we all got turns to do different things. It gave a real insight into how labour intensive this kind of food preparation is - all the fine chopping, then hand grinding of the flavourings for the dishes was what took most of the time. The dishes were all very different in their flavours. The eggplant sambal was a highlight as was the fern salad, and the mie goreng was delicious - so fresh and full of flavour. Any cooking class here is definitely worth taking - was disappointed that all the others during our stay were fully booked.

Just do it - you won't regret it.. A brilliant crowd of people.Excellent hibiscus tea.Good balance between hands on and hands off.Interesting cultural culinary context.Awesome lunch!Not yet repeated at home :(

Great cooking class, yummy food. I chose this cooking class after reading reviews on TripAdvisor. It was extremely well run, Oleg was a masterful teacher - charming, funny and engaging.Our group size was large, 12-15, however it wasn't an issue as we all (just) fitted around the demonstration tables and were able to try everything as we went, took turns on preparing and cooking the food, etc.The morning flew by and before we knew it we were sitting down to enjoy our creations.Overall a great experience, nice setting, wonderful teacher and assistants and very well organised and free-flowing class.Thank you, Casa Luna and Oleg!

A Must Do in Bali. We arrived at 9am along with about 12 others from all over the world and greeted and gives some hibiscus tea to try. For the first hour we sat at a lovely long table and listened to our Balinese Ched tell us all about Bali cooking ingredients especially the spices. It was enjoyable and we got to look rich and smell each spice we tales about. Then came the fun part of preparing all the food. We were shown how and then split up in small groups to split beans, grind peanuts, make chicken skewers, rice etc.It is not a day for kids up to 12 or 13 and even then they would really need to have an strong interest in cooking otherwise it would be quite boring for them. We had one very keen young man in our group but after 2 hrs he had really lost focus and his parents probably wished they had not brought him along ( for his sake)We got the recipes to bring home and we got to eat what we cooked which was a beautiful traditional Indonesian meal. I loved the freshly made satay from ground peanuts and spices. Highly recommend it!

Excellent and Informative. We did the Tuesday morning market tour and cookery school. The market tour was made interesting by our informative guide who was able to show us things we would not have know what they were. We then walked to Honeymoon 2 to take part in the cooking school. The teacher was excellent she had good english and a great sense of humour. We were shown several different dishes and were involved in the preparation of the dishes. We were quite a large group about 15 people so not everyone was able to have a go at the actual cooking, but that did not matter as you learnt more by watching. The lunch was very filling and mist enjoyable.

Authentic local food. I attended the Wednesday cooking class.Staff were all very welcoming and knowledgeable of the local food. Our instructor Yude made the class extremely enjoyable with her crack up jokes and stories. She really put a fun spin on the morning. She stepped us through the preparation and cooking of each dish so not too much work needed from our end. Food was delicious.

False Advertising. I recently attended the Saturday morning class. It is written up as food for health it was nothing to do with this. We cooked up the 2 base recipes and just left out the shrimp paste. One salad dressing was made and then used on the 3 salads provided. They advertised the recipe for non dairy coconut ice cream and although. We ate it at the end of the meal they refused to give the recipe to us. I have attended this cooking school before. It was very disappointing this time.
Delicious food!. My husband and I spent an afternoon at Casa Luna Cooking School and it was one well spent. The instructor was very helpful and easy to follow. The food - devine!

Excellent Thursday Night Market Tour. Fantastic!Together with just two other couples (for a total group size of six), our guide Pudi brought us to the night market in Gianyar just outside of Ubud. (We met at Casa Luna and then were provided a van to take the group to the market.) Gianyar is Pudi's hometown village and as soon as we got in the van and he started to talk about where we were headed, you could hear the pride in his voice.The Gianyar night market is the place where Balinese from all around the Ubud region dine for a special treat - and it is truly a treat! Stall after stall prepare their specialities from suckling pig to smoked chicken to satay and kebab to veggies and tofu and finally beautiful sweets. Date nights, family celebrations, and friend gatherings fill the seats in front of each of the stalls.Pudi walked the market with us, pointing out each of the dishes, explaining both the ingredients and the cooking method. He also shared with us how the Balinese chefs prepared the plates for their guests (including take-away options), and talked about how the family business operated to prepare the dishes and move their carts nightly to and from the market.We sampled dishes along the way, then sat down for a meal at one stall - and our meal included *everything* the market was selling! We were stuffed!!! After the meal we wandered a little bit more and again sampled along the way, this time the desserts and sweets.We could not have asked for a better experience! This market rarely see tourists and is truly how the Balinese cook and eat. And Pudi was outstanding as a guide - so affable, friendly, funny, informative and kind. He answered every question our group had - about the market, about Balinese cooking, about Balinese customs and habits, and about the Ubud region. If you'd like to escape the well-worn tourist roads - and restaurants - of Ubud and really see Bali and the Balinese culture around food, then this is your tour!Thank you Casa Luna for putting together such a great program! Well done!

Simple and interesting lesson . Casa Luna staff are very polite, knowledgeable and passionate about what they are doing. The basic course walks you through the main ingredients, tools and techniques of Balinese cuisine - knives, cutting boards, stone mortars. You don't get to do much, apart from cutting and stirring, but it is perfect if you're getting close to Asian cuisine for the first time or if you're not used to cooking every day.If experienced cook, the chef gives you further explanations and tips: they are very very polite and welcome all questions. Even for big groups,the basic course is good enough.The complementary cookbook / leaflet they gave us will be very useful back home, especially the suggested substitutions for typical Balinese ingredients not easily found in Europe.We would totally do one of their more advanced courses next time.

Pefect to learn balinese cooking. A really enjoyable time was spent at the cooking class.The classes are held in honeymoon 2 across the road from the honeymoon hotel in a large open building. The grounds are beautifully landscaped with courtyard pools and ponds as well pavillons to laze on if you arrive early. The staff are friendly and informative teaching you about all the different spices and balinese culture as well as passing on how to cook several balinese meals.They started with a spice talk and then moved on to meal prep. We where all involved in helping to prep all the ingredients and while we did the staff informed us about the equipment we used to do it and other foodie cultural things.We then got to eat the the beautifull food we had learnt to make.When leaving they gave us a little cook book that backed up all we had learntAll in all a fantasic foodie day talking food, making food and eating it.

Delicious Food. We didn't attend the cooking school but we ate dinner at the restaurant. The food was delicious and we considered coming back but in the end decided to try somewhere different. Had I stayed in Ubud longer, I would have come back.

Great experience. Went to the Wednesday class where they teach you to make traditional Balinese food. Was very enjoyable and interesting experience. Class was hosted by a lady from the local area and as well as explaining all about the local food she also gave an insight into the culture on the island. At the end all the food is served up and the meal was gorgeous , go just for this !!

Disappointing night market tour. My friend and I booked into the night market tour and 'open air feast' hoping for an exciting trip to the market followed by a great meal. The tour cost approx. $40 per person Australian which was expensive compared to other tours we had done but we thought the feast would make up for the extra cost. Unlike our other tours we had to make our own way into/out of Ubud from our hotel. The driver and tour guide were both excellent and well informed. The walk through the market was informative. As we walked we were provided with a taste of a cake from one stall and a delicious omelette inside a crepe from another. After less then an hour we returned to a stall where we were asked to sit on the wooden bench and were provided with a plastic plate of food from the stall and either a bottle of water or iced tea. Turns out this was the open air feast!! Both my friend and I were concerned about the food handling and the risk of becoming unwell so we only had a bite of the suckling pig. After this we were driven back to the centre of Ubud. in all we paid $40 for a 2 hour tour, a tiny piece of cake, shared omelette and taste of suckling pig - not my idea of a feast :(

Highlight of Bali. I really enjoy taking cooking classes and food tours when I travel as food is such an important part of any culture. I'd never had Indonesian food and was worried because I'd read that shrimp paste was in everything. They happily took shrimp paste off the menu for me and allowed me to cook with tempeh instead of chicken when making sate. I loved hearing about the different ingredients and what to use at home as a substitute. The food was incredible but mostly I liked the wonderful instructors who made it so much fun by cracking jokes, telling us about life in Ubud, and being so warm. It was a great half day adventure in a beautiful setting.
Cooking School. I did this cooking class today and it was so good. I'd well and truly recommend people to try this. I was amazed. I'll be back for sure.

Grossly Misleading advertising ..extremely disappointed ..Friday Night Market Tour. Firstly I would like to say that I have been in the hospitality industry for over 20 years and cooking is my passion..I am not one for starched white table clothes and prefer to eat local food. I own and have read Fragrant Rice 3 times I also own Janet's Bali cookbook and love it. I have traveled to many Asian country's but never to Bali. after spending a week in Bali I absolutely Love the people ,the food and the culture ..myself and friend from school day's in Melbourne have had a brilliant time.. We had Lunch at Indus one day and we both thought it was amazing ,Brilliant ..We also had dinner at Casa Luna and I could not rate it high enough. ..so much so we went back for an afternoon tea and again for a lunch all of which were faultless . I commented on how Fantastic the staff .were how . Beautiful the food was the Decor also Stunning in Indus and Casa Luna. I pre booked the Friday Night Market tour prior to Leaving Australia and I was extremely excited about going.. .this was going to be the highlight of our trip.. .. I am gob smacked at the fact we paid equivalent of $40 Aud pp .. Yes I was expecting a market..this I have no problem with.. yes I know it is local food..this excites me.. to be honest we both felt there must have been some mistake.. we were led to believe we were doing a night market tour then having an open air FEAST.. to be fair the tour guide and driver were fine but that is where it ends.. a stroll through a market ok . 1 bite of a sweet and sample of 1 other market food then told we are having the suckling pig ..all we wanted was to try a sample . but to say we were going to then have an open air feast ?? sorry $80 for 2 people to share a plate of food we didn't want or enjoy has left me feeling like I needed to say something .. we were expecting to maybe go to another location a Wayan or a set location at Market and have Dinner. but no that was it ...??? Love Casa Luna ...Love Indus.. Love Bali.. But Market tour ..?? don't understand why the standard did not continue.. Sorry :-( Didn't enjoy

Enjoyable informative experience. Went on the Gianyar night market trip and to the Bebek tutu class and thoroughly enjoyed both. So nice to get a taste of lots of things at the night market and the bebek tutu class was fantastic. Wonderful to see the whole process with the betel nut palm leaf and rice husk to cook. Really liked the hibiscus drink and seeing the magic of making it. The staff were really lovely. Found the spiciness too toned down as they refuse to believe that Australians really like hot spicy. Had to wait until visiting an Indonesian cafe in Melbourne on my way home to get the real thing. Still really recommend.

Thoroughly enjyable. Haven't done a cooking class since my first trip here 15 years ago so decided to do the Saturday morning vegetarian class. Had a wonderful competent instructor as well as his assistants. Very informative about the benefits of the ingredients, substitutes, insights the fact that saffron in the markets isn't saffron after all ect. Yes all you do is a bit of chopping and stirring, making spice paste but the whole package is great fun. And you get to eat what is made. We had a wonderful International bunch of people that added to the experience. Would go to another one again.

A taste experience. Enjoyed a very pleasant morning exploring the colourful world of Balinese cooking. Even had an introduction to the herbs and spices used and substitutions if any were hard to locate. The food we assisted with was beautiful.

Beginners cooking - Friday class. Great introduction to Indonesian cuisine, flavours and ingredients. Had hoped to be a little more hands on but enjoyed just the same. The food we created was amazing!

Disappointing. My friend and I were looking forward to attending the cooking school and booked several weeks before we travelled to Bali. We needed to check 2 days before the class to ensure it would go ahead as there is a minimum class requirement of 4 students. We thought there was a possibility that the class wouldn't go ahead. Our husbands volunteered to come to the class if the minimum number wasn't reached as they knew we were anxious but keen to do the class. The class was confirmed 2 days before.On the day of the class we set off into town to the class. We did however get lost on the way as there are no signs to indicate where the cooking school is. We nearly gave up, but asked for directions twice, kept going and finally arrived 30 minutes late. There were 11 other people in the class.The menu was typically balinese, very highly spiced. Students were able to contribute to the chopping and preparation. However I had some food safety concerns about the teachers cooking style. The class was a bit tedious and slow.Students were able to eat the food prepared at the completion of the class. There was plenty of food to enjoy and a booklet of recipes was provided.My friend and I were disappointed and cancelled the market tour we had booked for later in the week.

Great class to learn about balinese smoked duck!. We went to the Sunday smoked duck class and loved it. The teacher was very funny and energetic. She was good at explaining all the different ingredients and having us participate in the preparation. Because smoking a duck takes so long, we started the proces, but actually ate ducks that had been smoking all day. Apparently the staff get a nice breakfast on Monday morning. The staff were kind enough to provide with mosquito repellent which is well needed. The food was great and included a bunch of side dishes: lawar, chicken kare, pickled carrots and yellow rice. The dessert was coconut ice cream with jackfruit and mung bean. Excellent class. If we had once complaint, it's that it wasn't 100% hands on... we helped chop all the herbs and grind the spice paste, but when it came to actually assembling and cooking the dishes, staff did most of the work.

Disappointed. Called early morning to see if they had room for one. The person I talked to said yes, be at the guest house by 8 am. So I grab a taxi get there right on time at 8. Guy at the desk tells me it's next door at the restaurant. Ask the restaurant they said they met at the salon .5 k away and she will tell the group to wait. Get there and no one is around. Call the guy he says they are already gone. Hangs up. Anyway I can't comment on the cooking but it was definitely a waste of my time.
Great experience. Really enjoyed our morning at the Casa Luna cooking school. Stunning setting, lovely 'teacher', fresh ingredients and great food.

Sunday night - Smoked duck. Our driver dropped us off at the Cafe Luna restaurant which was a 20 min hike with a lot of uphill to the Cooking School. The refreshing iced hibiscus tea was a life saver. We had a compatible group of German, Aussie and US guests who had a good time sharing the chopping, shredding and mashing to ready the seasonings for both the duck and the green bean/coconut dish. As smoking the duck takes four or more hours, we were shown the prep, but they provided the finished meat which was yummy. Seeing the mountain of rice hulls that added the smoke to the betel leaf to the seasonings, and then tasting it was great. Every dish was just of the edge of too peppery for me, but I loved every bite. Just made my nose run. If I'm ever back this way, I hope to be able to do the market tour class.

Fabulous . We did the market tour and had the privilege of Janet's presence, I could babble on, but the simple reactions between her and her staff stand testament to the respect between them her priceless looks when the advice from her staff to add more of a particular ingredient shows how ingrained the respect is, a great day out would recommend it any level of cooking skill.

Delicious, fun and a great experience. I've taken the morning market tour class before, just 3 months ago, and had a great time so I was keen to come again with a friend.We booked for the Sunday twilight Smoked Duck Class - the class size for this is smaller than the usual day classes and this works really well. I enjoyed learning about all of the different ingredients and being able to touch and smell all of them. We didn't get to cook the duck as it is smoked for 8 hours but we were shown all of the stages of preparation and cooking so we didn't miss anything. The instructor was an absolute stand out for me. She was so friendly and funny. I was curious about home life and family and she was happy to answer all of my questions. This lady is an absolute credit to cooking school and is the biggest reason why the classes are so great.This is not the style of cooking school where each person has their own station and cook every dish themselves from scratch - instead it is more of a demonstration where participants can join in and have a go at each stage. I much prefer this as it allowed me to relax and ask questions and just observe when I wanted to and it also allowed us to chat with the others in the class. We had a lovely time, met some great people and the feast at the end was fabulous.I wouldn't hesitate to recommend Casa Luna cooking school to friends and I will certainly be back to try more classes when I visit again.

Great value - fresh food. I enjoyed the day but as a person who would rather eat than cook - this was a bit boring for me. My other 5 friends loved it though and it was interesting to learn about ingredients etc. We went for afternoon tea to Casa Luna Cafe and had delicious afternoon tea - lime tart to die for!!!
The greatest time!. We book with one week in advance and cooked with a group of 6 people more. I recommend the Begginers Class and we cooked Nasi Goreng.The place is great to learn!

We had fun preparing and stuffing ourselves with delicious food. We loved the course. The instructor was funny and informative, about food and Bali. The helpers were by professional and interesting. We prepared multiple dishes that we enjoyed at the end...don't plan on needing dinner after the course. The most delicious food we had in our whole three weeks in Bali. We learned a lot, got a little recipe book and can't wait to apply some of our new skills at home...although the setting won't be near as lovely. We were a bit disappointed that we missed out on the market tour as it was already full but the one we took was also excellent.
very tasty!. this mark goest to Luna Cafe, been there four times in ten days, just prefect. everything i ordered i was satisfied with, especially those all-day breakfasts and healthy drinks

Fantastic Experience. Can't speak highly enough of this cooking class in Ubud. It was an insight into the food of Bali and the ingredients that make this crisis so special. Our host was knowledgable and used humour to entertain us with stories of food and culture. We were able to join in the preparation of the food and then got to enjoy it at the end. This was some of the best eating during our stay in Bali. Highly recommend!

Really fun day. We attended as a family, 2 children and 2 adults. We had the best fun. Our host was really good fun and the food we cooked from scratch, learning all of the techniques and the names of all of the ingredients. After we all took it in turns assisting our chef, we go to eat it all.

Excellent Cooking Class. We enjoy food and have always liked taking a cooking class to acquaintance ourselves better with the culture and preparation of the different ingredients. The tuition was hands on, humorous and very informative. And we couldn't eat it all!

Two Great cooking Classes. On a recent trip to Ubud, I signed up for two cooking classes. They were both great. The first was a Sunday night smoked duck class. Although we did prepare the duck, we ate one that had been cooking in the ground for more than 8 hours. The people running the class were knowledgable and friendly and since there were only 3 of us in the class we got to do quite a bit to prepare our feast which we later ate. The explanations and the processes for preparation and cooking were clearly and simply explained and we were given copies of all the recipes. The second class started with a trip to the morning market where real Balinese people do their shopping. It was fascinating and our guide was helpful in pointing out all the sights and explaining the process to us. we then went back to the kitchen and prepared chicken curry and several amazingly delicious side dishes. There were 12 of us and we still got to prepare and cook as much as we wanted. We then feasted on all we cooked, again receiving all the recipes. I highly recommend Casa Luna cooking school. It's a great way to cook and eat Balinese food.

Ubud Cooking Experience. First time i have done a cooking class experience and the level of hands on involvement is your choice. We met at Casa Luna and did the market tour first and learn't about our ingredients and then a short walk to the cooking school. The cooking instructors were lovely and even better to enjoy the fruits of our labours with a lovely Indonesian Banquet, a great experience not to be missed.

Best food I ate (and cooked) in Ubud!. I had heard about Casa Luna, as Janet de Neef had spoken at Darwin festival, where I live and wanted to get some Indonesian inspiration- as we grow very similar produce and I love a good food story and also run food workshops/ projects. There are many cooking schools in Ubud and I am sure many of these are also good and worth checking out, but I had heard Casa Luna was a wonderful restaurant with great tasting local/ fusion food- and I was not disappointed at all. The food we cooked was the best I had eaten in my stay in the now sadly overcrowded town of restaurants and tourists and building projects. I attended both a Saturday class- Food as medicine (veggie) and the Monday class- Fish Curries etc. (see their website for menu details beforehand) The presenter, Aday was great, and I loved her stories and insight to a little of Bali culture. I felt, as a holiday cooking class- rather than full on, there was enough hands if you wanted and some parts were pre cooked/ prepped or demoed, which was fine by me. The ingredients were all explained and so fresh and local and the food we cooked both days was so delicious, authentic tasty Balinese, and in a beautiful setting. If anything I would have loved to know a little more about food origins particularly farming styles and organic methods or not) and on the food as medicine day, I did not feel more was explained about the health properties of the ingredients than the other class. We had small classes of 5 people, then 12- which was great and got to meet other food loving people. I would avoid larger classes- probably in high season, as I think it would be a bit inpersonal (maybe check the day before) Overall though I had a great experience and would love to go and check out the restaurant as attention to flavour was so good, and the Bali cook book is also a great read!

Great cooking class. An excellent way to learn about balinese cooking - right amount of hands on avtivity, beautiful surroundings, gorgeous instructors and assistants. My friends and I felt this was the highlight of our 5 days in bali.

A must do in Ubud. We went on a market tour on Thursday night. Our guide Panda and driver drove us out to a village to see and eat where the locals eat, the night market is open until midnight. Panda explained the dishes to us as we walked through the market, ingredients used and the difference between the dishes. We got to try a variety of food as we walked around and sat down to have a meal at the end of the tour. This tour was a highlight of my visit to Bali, panda was a great tour guide and I loved tasting the different dishes. Anyone who loves to cook should do this tour!

Memorable experience, highly recommended. I spent a wonderful morning taking the Market Tour cooking class on a Tuesday.Meeting at Casa Luna restaurant we have a group of around 15 people - myself, an American couple, a group of women from Melbourne and a group of women from Iceland. Our friendly guide explains that he will take us to the market, show us around and give us time to buy anyhting we want before brining us back to the hotel for the cooking school. We take a short walk to the market and we are guided around and he shows us different fruits and vegetables, spices and cooking equipment and explains them all to us. We are able to taste most things and given time to buy anything we want although not pressured to buy anything at all. It gets quite warm and we are standing for a while so I buy a fan to keep myself cool.We take another short walk back past Casa Luna Restaurant to Honeymoon Guesthouse for the cooking school. We are given morning tea - chilled hibiscus tea, cold water, a rice dish and a curry dish and some small pandan coconut pikelets with palm sugar syrup. We move on to the cooking and we are joined by Janet De Neefe, the owner, who takes over teaching the class. We are shown all of the ingredients we are going to use and Janet gives us a great background on how they are used in traditional Indonesian cooking. The class takes turns to chop and prepare ingredients then to grind them on large mortar and pestles then some of the class cook and assemble the food.Finally we are left with a large feast of food that we serve ourselves and sit down to eat together. Urab Pakis (my favourite dish of the day), Kare Tempeh, Sambal Tuwung, Sambal Matah, Sambal Goreng, Mie Goreng and Ikan Mekuah. Dessert of green coconut pancakes is prepared for us while we eat but we are given the recipe for this and everything else we made.How much you participate in this class is up to you - if you prefer to sit back and watch you can do so or you can get in and try your hand at preparing most things. You don't get to prepare every dish yourself from scratch as you might in other cooking schools but this is still a very informative and entertaining class. Thank you to Janet and her staff for being so friendly and welcoming.

Good but not the best. Went for dinner in the evening with my the other half. Ambience was good, the ground floor have nice decoration facing the road. the Casa lunar bar at B1 have nice scenery at the back and is cooler. (you can choose either place for your dinner). Food is good and nicely presented but not excellent. The service can be furher improved but i cannot find any thing to fault the waitress.Advice: they have different events/performances at different time of the week(and the time table do change), do check the time table before going.
Great cocktails. Called in for happy hour at casa luna. Cocktails are cheaper between 5-7pm. Plenty to chose from, the location is nice.

Spices and new friends. A wonderful day learning new skills in the kitchen. It was exactly what was suggested on their website. A day learning about food, preparing, cooking and eating wonderful food.

great morning. Had the pleasure of attending a Friday morning cooking class recently. We had a great time and Olag and Made were great with our group of 10 and spent quite a bit of time explaining the ingredients traditionally used in Bali. Class is not as hands on as I have previously experienced, mostly chopping, stirring etc but still enough.We had a great feast prepared after a few hours. And was lovely to meet people who were visiting Bali. Would recommend

Time to clean out my pantry.
