After spending 4 hours with a wonderfully funny and skilled teacher I have decided to abandon my usual ingredients and recipes and concentrate on using the beautifully aromatic spices and ingredients which are the basis of Indonesian food. We were given a welcome drink which was made from the red hibiscus petals and then shown all the ingredients (with explanations of their primary uses and some helpful tips for medicinal purposes) that we were to use in our menu. I loved the end result of fish curry, BBQ fish in banana leaves and most amazing salads. There was a large group of us attending the class and we all agreed it had been an amazing experience.

A must for all cooks. Had the best day at the Casa Luna Cooking school - the lady who ran the class was so great (cant remember her name)and all her helpers. Would really recommend this to anyone who loves good food. The beast meal we had in Bali !!!

Not really a cooking class. I know that good cooking is in the prep - but cutting spices and veges is not a cooking class, or stirring a few things while cooking. The staff did most of the actual cooking including the prep cooking. Uday - the 'head chef' very friendly and informative. But not really a cooking class as such - however, the meal produced was an excellent tasting of food - just not cooked by the class as such.

Fabulous cooking class. This was a fabulous fun day. We prepared everything from scratch under the helpful and watchful eyes of the friendly staff. We sat and ate a banquet prepared with our own hands. Learnt plenty and would highly recommend this experience to everyone!

New Food as Medicine. For the most part I enjoyed this experience. However, unfortunately Janet de Neefe, the founder of Casa Luna, and who I'd hoped would be taking the class, was on a plane to Melbourne where I'd come from! Her senior Balinese chef - Uday, I think, was lovely, but very chatty with her personal stories! I would have enjoyed more knowing that Janet was taking the class.

Well done Casa Luna. Being that I love to cook, I researched a number of cooking classes in the Ubud area before I chose Casa Luna.We chose the Tuesday Market Tour class which started at 8am at the restaurant to meet our guide + group to take us through the local markets. Truly an amazing and eye opening experience people watching as well as learning about local produce and spices.At about 10am we were then guided back to the honeymoon resort and introduced to our teacher, Yudi who was lovely. She provided us with morning tea/breakfast of local porridge and gadogado before we started the class.We were lucky and only had a class of 12 ppl, apparently the smallest class is past couple of months being that we are now at the end of the high season. Perfect amount.After being assigned a chopping block and knife we were all given different preparation roles for various dishes which were on the menu.Tempe/tofu curry, Marlin fish curry, mie Goreng, fern salad, sambals, roasted white eggplant w tomatoes all amazing, as the group all sits down and enjoys at the end.Well worth the Rp350,000 for something a bit different and some delicious food.Open 7 days/week and each day has a theme. Tuesday was home local home cooking, but other days include vegetarian, traditional/ceremonial, basic Indonesian, currys etcWell done Casa Luna

Fantastic cooking experience.. This was a great way to spend a Sunday evening. Our entertaining cooking guide showed and shared her experiences of cooking traditional food. The evenings dish was Betutu Bebek - Smoked Duck. A great way to meet fellow travelers with a similar interest in local cuisine. There were many other options to choose from through the week. Can't wait for our next trip to Ubud!

Night Market Tour a "must"!. This is a tour operated by Casa Luna Cooking School, & booked via the restaurant. Our guide, Pandi, took us in a minibus to the markets at Gianyar, a little way out of Ubud. There were only 2 of us on the trip. This was not so much a produce market - more many, many different food stalls selling prepared foods - suckling pig, satays, fried chicken, you name it. Just fascinating, & Pandi was able to explain to us how many of the dishes were prepared. The evening ended with a taste of some of the foods. This was a traditional market, we saw maybe half-a-dozen tourists amongst the crowds of locals during the 2 or so hours that we were there. Fabulous!

Nervous. Although I do most of the cooking at home I was somewhat nervy about this class.Aussie Janet and her crew are just great and eased my brain so I could function.I did the market day.You visit the markets in the centre of Ubud to collect the ingredients for the days menu.Bustling and worth a visit to experience the local people and their wares.The class was a mixed bunch,men ,girls,youngish,oldish.All wanting to get that special knowledge that makes Balinese food so yummy.I did ok.There wasn't too much serious lessening but just the same you learnt.You get to eat the prepared meals we all made and have a laugh.

Excellent! . Very friendly staff, and the owner is great at what she does. Good instructions, and the food in the end was excellent. However, at least with the Monday class, you don't make your own dish. Everyone is participating in making one common meal, so while you're cutting ginger, you're missing how the other ingredients are treated. I would have liked to prepare one portion from start to finish. You do however get the recipes explained well in a pamphlet you receive.

Excellent. Delicious and Inspiring.. Thank you to Yudi and crew for 3 fabulous days of cooking and feasting. Entertaining, informative and a whole lot of fun. I really feel that we had the real deal on Balinese cooking. I shall be able to follow Janet DeNeefs recipes from her latest book with more ease. Highly recommended.

Night market tour - loved it!. Went on the night market tour and it was fantastic. My wife and I were the only ones and there was a guide and a driver. They pick you up at Casa luna in a nice SUV and you drive maybe 20 minutes outside of town. Our guide, Pandi, then explained dozens of types of market food and snacks. Along the way you can eat or get take away anything that you want. At the end, we dug into a roasted pig (babi guling or lechon) plate of food. Highly recommended for anyone who cherishes the aspect of food when traveling - you will learn all the names of food and get to try them.

Second serv!!. My husband & I returned after 2 years. We got so much out of the first visit that we have been having Bali nights in Perth with our friends & cooking up a storm ever since. Our friends & relatives have commented on how authentic the food tastes. Although the cooking school may not be as hands on as some people would like, I think it depends on what you want to get out of it. Which for us is watching, learning & listening and seeing the order that ingredients get incorporated into the dishes. We also like the fact it's only half a day out of our holiday relaxing time unlike some cooking schools which go on most of the day. We loved our second visit even though we repeated some old ground, it's always good to refresh. The setting is very Balinese & inviting, the staff are warm & friendly and when you think about value compared to other cooking schools, it really is excellent. Considering you get morning tea, unlimited refreshments & a huge lunch. I don't think the value can be beaten. We were lucky to have Janet teach our class. As we have eaten at all Janet's restaurants several times & I am a big fan of her book Fragrant Rice, it was great to meet her in person. She is a charming lady & very knowledgeable. We can't wait to return to learn to cook some more dishes!!!!

Sensational spices. This was my first every cooking class, so I did not know what to expect. Yudi ran the class of 12. She explained all the spices we would be using,the meals we would be cooking and talked about local traditions, dos and don'ts at the food markets.I did the Wednesday class which was cooking ceremonial food.Then it was down to grinding spices, grinding peanuts for the satay sauce, making the chicken skewers. Next it was down to eating what we made. Absolutely beautiful.Would I make it at home? Yes, but it would be far easier to get the spices out of a jar than gather up to 16 different spices.

Excellent class. I have attended the Casa Luna Cooking School 3 times over the past 8 years and it's always excellent. This class is all about learning and you sure learn an enormous amount about spices, medicinal benefits and local culture. There were only 8 in our class, sometimes there have been a few more. The price is great - you get loads of food, hibiscus tea, rice wine and a nice book of recipes.The tutors are fun and extremely friendly too. On Mondays and Tuesdays Janet De Neefe, the owner, takes the class with her team.

Enjoyable morning, very informative. This cooking class was very enjoyable we learnt all about the local spices and herbs, the teacher was very funny, friendly and informative which made for a very enjoyable time. We got to try there techniques of food preparation if you wanted to. There was no pressure to actually cook or chop any food but we were most welcome to try. Was a really fun experience and the food was really good and they catered for vegetarians. So much to eat.

Not hands-on, really disappointing. First the good stuff: this cooking school is in a beautiful location in an open air kitchen surrounded by Balinese decor and architecture, the food was pretty good, and the staff was very nice. However, those two features aren't necessarily the keys to what I am looking for in a cooking school, and the negative aspects of this experience unfortunately outweigh the positives. First, the class is not at all hands-on, and I think the website is dishonest in omitting this from the description. In a 3.5 hour class, I think I got in three minutes of cooking: I chopped a few cucumbers, I smashed some ingredients into a paste, and I wrapped a fish in banana leaves. All of the prepping and chopping was done for us, the dessert was entirely made in advance, and even much of what we were supposed to be cooking was done in a separate room. I felt like I mostly heard an hour long lecture about spices. On top of that, our instructor Uday, who was obviously a very nice woman, spent at least 25 minutes (I timed it) talking about her kids, her education, her health, the number of boyfriends she used to have, how she adopted her child, her mother, etc. I'm not callous, but honestly, that was not appropriate for the class and the time could have been much better spent cooking and not listening to tales from her personal life. I don't know HOW this got onto some list of best cooking schools in the world: I've been to cooking schools in Marrakesh, Paris, Rome, and Washington DC and this was by far the worst.

Disappointing...Not what we expected. I wish I had taken the time to read TA reviews prior to booking this activity, then I would've know that it wouldn't be enjoyable for my daughters and me. Our only other cooking school experience was in Cambodia. For $5 each in Cambodia, we spent 2 hours and prepared 3 different delicious Cambodian dishes with a total of 4 people. That was my point of reference when my daughters suggested we try a cooking class in Ubud. Unfortunately, it was what we were expecting to do (but for $30USD instead of $5).As other reviewers have mentioned, it's more of a lecture and demonstration. The first 1.5 hours were spent sitting around a table with 15 other people listening to descriptions of all of the spices and ingredients. The next 1.5 hours were mostly observing the 2 ladies in charge prepare everything. We were given brief "turns" to mash peanuts, dice cucumbers, and skewer chicken satays. These turns were mainly photo ops. You are by no means preparing a meal yourself.On the bright side, the food we did eat was fantastic. They were also gracious and invited my husband to eat the lunch also even though he didn't participate in the class. In hindsight, I would have much preferred spending 3 hours exploring Ubud, and then going to their restaurant for lunch. It would have cost much less than $90USD and would have been more fun.

Very interesting but not hands on cooking. I attended the Tuesday class at casa luna and had a nice time but the class had more than 20 people and although the food was delicious we didn't cook it ourselves. We occasionally rotated using the mortar and pestle or stirring the wok but mostly we watched each other or Janet and the other staff. The market tour was interesting but our class was too big to move through easily. It was definitely an enjoyable morning but if you really want to cook it's not the best.

true balinese food. I love cooking and learning new recepies, so in my visit to Ubud I couldn't miss a cooking course.After reading the lonley planet guide I decided to book my cooking course with them.The teacher was great, she first introduced us the ingredients and then the cooking started.What can I say, it was all great!The only two negative points, is for me, I like to learn dish by dish but here we went through all the dishes at the same time. We first did all the spice mixing of the different dishes, so at the end you don't remember what went with what. Second thing is the duration of the class, from 9 till 13, quite short if you are trying to learn.have said that, I will recomend this place to everybody!

Cooks holiday. My son and I went to the Monday class which does not include the market tour. There were 10 people altogether which was a nice size group. Despite missing out on the market, we had a comprehensive class, beginning with a workshop on the spices and other ingredients used in Indonesian cooking, then on to cook the most fabulous dishes including a delicious fish curry. Thank you Janet and your staff for such an interesting class. Highly recommended for cooks of all ages and skills.

Fantastic food, knowledgeable but avoid market tour. Although I left this class with mixed feelings, overall it was an enjoyable experience. We started with the market tour, the guide knowledgeable and interesting, with opportunities to buy food/knives at select stalls for those inclined. However with our group size of 16 it wasn't practical, and we only heard about half of what the guide had to say. Throughout the cooking class there were plenty of different foods for us to try which were absolutely delicious!! We learnt a lot about cooking methods and Balinese culture, the staff pleasant and happy to answer anyone's questions. There was not a lot of hands on cooking involved which was a little disappointing. But overall we left with with full and happy stomachs.

Authentic Indonesian cooking in great atmosphere. I took my daughter here (14 yo) and we had a great day of watching someone cook a whole range of local dishes. We of course, got to eat them as well. The frangipani cocktail was particularly delicious. You can partly help out but mostly it's watching someone prepare the food in front of you. Janet, the owner wasn't there on the day and we had an excellent replacement. You do need to book well in advance. There are different menus on each day so you can choose a day that is preparing food you may like to watch being made.Cost is reasonable, I think it was $40 each and we took home a booklet of recipes which I've used since.Note: you will probably be with around 15 other people so it's not a private cooking lesson.

Great experience, both fun and interesting!. We did the cooking class with market tour on Thursday morning and I am really glad we did, because at the market we were told all sorts of little facts about the food, spices and utensils that are sold there and their purpose in Balinese life, which in my opinion really adds to the whole cooking experience. You also get the chance to buy some products at the market, but our tip is to go back by yourself another time to buy the things you want, because if you go to the downstairs area in the back, you get much better prices. During the tour however there is no time to stop there to buy too. Our tourguide at the market was a very friendly and knowlegeable guy, who made the tour a lot of fun, and looked out for us so no one would be left behind.After the market visit we went back to the honeymoon resort for the cooking class. First we had a short break with some refreshing drinks and a few Balinese snacks, which were delicious! We had a short introduction and the lovely woman who would be our teacher told us a little bit about herself (she is actually a stand-up comedian too!), which for me gave the whole thing a very personal touch. After the drinks it was time to put on our aprons and start preparing the food. We got elaborate explanations on the ingredients used and their purpose. Insights on Balinese cooking and family life were also part of the package. Everyone got a chance to participate, in the preparation as well as in the cooking. All the recipes and some information about the ingredients used were provided to us in a nice leaflet to take home.We all enjoyed the meal together with a nice glass of rice wine. During the meal they prepared our dessert, sago pudding, which was a perfect way to end the class. The 5 hours the class lasted just flew right by.Overall we are very pleased with the way the class turned out. The food was great, the market was educative, the cooking was fun, but what really made our day was the amazing warm, friendly, open attitude and sense of humour of the staff that provided the class. Chapeau! And thank you again. You really made it so much fun. When we will cook your dishes at home, we will definitely remember this class with a smile!We recommend this cooking class (especially with the market tour!) to everyone who is sincerely interested in cooking great fresh dishes and in Balinese culture, and loves to have a good time in the kitchen!

Shop, Cook, eat. I attended the Tuesday morning market tour and cookery lesson. It was wonderful. I gained a real insight into local ingredients from our guide who is a local and a chef. I now know how to choose vanilla, the best mangosteen and am able to identify and know what all the exotic fruits and vegetables are used for. He also explained what European substitutes we could use if certain ingredients were unavailable. We also gained insight into what the local prices should be. The market tour was then followed by a hands on cookery class held at the Casa Luna bungalows. A really pretty property not far from the market. We were first served a traditional breakfast deliciously spicy porridge and a spicy rice cake dish. We learned how to make fresh curry pastes for the fish curry and the vegetarian curry we would make. We made a total of five delicious dishes. We then sat and had the best typical meal of the trip. If you like cooking and eating this is a top choice.

I loved the chicken and duck cooking classes. This is an affordable way to meet people, learn how to cook amazing food and have a delicious meal. The facilitators were friendly and helpful. You get a little book to write notes and the class is very hands-on. I recommend these classes to everyone!

A great investment of time and money!. This was the best 5 hours I spent in Ubud! For $35 I received an education in shopping at the traditional market (before 10am each day if you want to secure the prices locals pay rather than enjoy a 50% increase paid by tourists!). Following the tour, the Casa Luna cooking school staff treated us to a morning tea complete with a demonstration for making hibiscus tea from a fresh flower. The cooking class covered the preparation of 5 mainstays of Balinese cuisine, including my favorite...Mie Goreng (fried noodles).The instructor, Yudi, shared tips and techniques for cooking Balinese food which she had learned from her mother. We learned the proper way to grind ingredients into a paste using a Balinese mortar and pestle as well as knife techniques for preparing vegetables without bruising them. The best tip, "Cook when you're happy." From the energy and enthusiasm she demonstrated during the class I suspect she is ALWAYS happy! :-) The class takes place at the Honeymood Guest House down the street from the restaurant in a spacious beautifully decorated open kitchen surrounded by lush landscaping.The best part of all...we ate our creations for lunch!

coconut sugar & sea salt tour. we did a trip to a family coconut nectar sugar place. it was brilliant watching the process of how to get the delicious sugar from the coconut nectar, start to finish with a sample to take home. we also saw how sea salt is produced. both processes were so sustainable and environmentally friendly. price included travel to the sites, plus lunch. highly recommend this tour. now I can enjoy sugar and not feel guilty, something straight from nature.

great!. I'm not a natural cook but I had such a fun time at the Friday beginners course. While you don't actually do all of the cooking, you're involved in preparation. And the food- WOW! So, delicious. Thank you very much to Oleg, Yudi and all the staff.

Fun, friendly and positive class. The teacher of the cooking class was fantastic! Very funny, enthusiastic and easy to talk to! Food was abundant and the snacks and free drinks they gave us was ver kind and thoughtful.

delicious and insightful. I have long been a fan of the food served at Janet de Neefe's restaurants in Ubud and so I was looking forward to taking the Monday class where recipes that I had cooked at home were being presented. These were more complicated than the basic classes and did not involve a trip to the market. I don't particularly like Asian markets apart from the fruit and veg section - everything else is too confronting and smelly for my pampered western senses.The location is quite easy to get to and is held at the drop dead gorgeous apartments that are just across the road from the older section of the Honeymoon guest house. We started off with a local Balinese woman who spoke excellent English giving us a description/background to Balinese cooking and the different ingredients we would be using. These were passed around our group of 12 people to sniff and taste while we waited for Janet to arrive. While she talked others were slicing and dicing the ingredients that would go into our lunch.Some reviews have complained that this class lacks a "hands on experience". This is true but as someone who does cook Indonesian style food I know just how much time it takes to prepare the ingredients and how dangerous the knives can be so for me it was fine to have others prepare while I watched in amazement at how dextrous they were with choppers/knives and cleavers. We got a taste of how much energy goes into the preparation of ingredients when we all took turns at grinding the paste. Janet was delightful as an instructor - she must have presented classes so many times but her talk was friendly, fresh, natural and responsive to our questions. And she does it all while wearing high heels!The food "we" cooked was delicious and I went away with greater insight into how the ingredients were sourced and how the food should be prepared as well as a booklet of the recipes presented that day.I booked this over the internet but did not pay the R350,000 each until we arrived in Ubud a few days before the Monday class.

Enjoyed. My week experience in Ubud has been consumed with accommodation woes. This morning I was on the streets at 7.00am following a sleepless night hoping to drop my luggage at new abode booked online overnight on route to Casa Luna. I need to say this as I have just read the reviews and whilst I agree with what they say I found this tour to be one of the highlights of my visit. The market tour criticisms are valid however im a solo traveller and just manoeuvre myself so I can hear the guide. In terms of my food knowledge I was more than satisfied and ofcourse really happy that Janet was present and to be honest they had to encourage food preparation participation. Maybe not so good for those that want to have a complete hands on experience. The food was delicious and im seriously hoping theres a room available when I return to Ubud in September. Suggestion - for those complaining about the market experience you must go to Vietnam and do Nevilles ' A taste of Hoi Ann' its a 10/10 experience

A little disappointing. I had looked forward to attending Janet's cooking class since my first visit to Ubud over 12 years ago. I even booked our class 2 months in advance - that's how eager I was. So when I realised there were around 18 people in my class I was not jumping with joy. The market tour was thoroughly disappointing. As other reviewers have mentioned, it was more of a money making campaign for a few select store owners. We did not buy the ingredients for the food we were making, but did spend a good 10 minutes looking at knives and were encourages to buy a whole number of weird things.The class simply had far too many people in it and wasn't hands on enough. Because of this people's attention drifted (including mine) and began chatting to themselves.Although the finished product food was excellent, I really need to rate this the lowest of all cooking classes I have experienced across the globe. Sorry Janet, I love you and what you've done and am totally jealous of your life - but you need to readdress the way you conduct these classes.

Great food and experience. We started at about 8am for the vegetarian cooking class. After taking a tour through the market, we sat down to various tasters and hibiscus tea. Our cooking guide was fantastic and made the course that more interesting. She mixed personal experiences in with her teaching. We cooked a tofu curry, coconut salad and mi goreng. If I had one criticism it would be I would have liked a bit more hands on experience. The staff cooked and prepared most of the food - we got to crush up the curry paste and chop up some veges. Great way to meet interesting people And discover new recipes.

A wonderful taste and Ubud experience. I booked a cooking school for my daughter and myself in February to do in first week of June. The booking process was very efficient and communication and queries promptly answered. The school was fantastic and interesting and although perhaps not as interactive as one I have done in Chiangmai, it was a great learning experience. Wonderful environment and staff..I bought the mortar and pestle and one day later I have it seasoned and oiled and ready to use.

Awesome food with a fun group. I have been to Bali many times but each time missed out on going to this cooking class. We were in Bali over my Birthday so that is the first tour I booked in. Picked up by a driver early on Monday morning from Seminyak and we headed out to Ubud. The drive out itself was really pretty. We had an really nice group doing the class with us. A Balinese lady taught us first and she was very funny and friendly, and Janet came later on. If you want to have Janet at the class we were told the best days to go are Mondays and Tuesdays. Everyone got a go at either pounding spices in the Mortar and Pestle or cooking something, with tasting along the way. I would highly recommend this class to anyone wanting to take cooking skills home. My husband bought Janets cookbook and had her sign it for me as a Birthday suprise. I have cooked a few of the receipes at home and the smells remind me of this very fun day.
Great fun experience. Did a cooking class to learn more about Indonesian cuisine and also took a tour with them to the Giyanar Night Market - amazing look at local food.

Good cooking class, disappointing market tour. Took the Thursday market tour and cooking lesson on May 9th.Really disappointed with the market tour. Our group was 18 people in size and simply too big for everyone to hear. Our guide spoke quietly and was unable to speak to the group as a whole, it was really frustrating and disappointing.Before the cooking class began we had some hibiscus tea and food which was lovely. The lady who ran the class was lovely- very friendly, welcoming and funny.The cooking class was partly observation, but every effort was made to include us and answer questions. Also received a pamphlet providing lots of information on recipes. Food was delicious.If I did it again i wouldn't bother with the market tour as it really was disappointing and many people in our group expressed a similar opinion.

A wonderful Masterclass!. I recently returned to Ubud and booked in for a second cooking class at Casa Luna. This time, we were lucky to have Janet attend and assist with the class. Once again, the staff at the cooking school were entertaining, informative and friendly. The food we made was delicious and the entire group (I think there were about 16 in the class) enjoyed themselves.If you are looking for an enjoyable way to spend a morning, book in now. At approximately $35AUD it is worth it.

A bit of a let down. This is a hard review for me to write :(. This is very hard review for me to write as I have a high regard for Janet De Neefe who runs/owns the Casa Luna Rest. and Honeymoon Guesthouses and I love, absolutely LOVE her book Fragrant Rice - which I cook from at home all the time.I have done numerous cooking classes through out Asia and was really looking forward to doing a Casa Luna Cooking class. Unfortunately this was more of a cooking demonstration then a hands on class. Although I was hoping Janet herself would be the teacher (but wasn't), this was only a very small disappointment, as the teacher who gave the class had been with Casa Luna for some 20years and teaching for 10years. This teacher (a local Balinese) was lovely, very informative and understandable, and delightfully funny.To begin with, we all met at Casa Luna at 8am, walked to the market and had a tour of the market. The chap taking us was fantastic - really interesting! The downside was that we were 'encouraged' to buy items he recommended, but the food we were cooking was not purchased at the market whilst we were there - in all the other Asian cooking classes I've done in other countries, the produce we're cooking were purchased at the same time as the tour and we see how they choose the produce. We then all returned to the Honeymoon Guesthouse (which is absolutely beautiful !) and to my disappointment all the produce we would be cooking with had been pre-prepared. The only cutting required was of some beans and an eggplant. The only 'hands-on' the students had was taking turns (very short turns) in grinding the spices together and two students were allowed to stir the curry mixture. Most of the cooking was done by another staff member whilst the teacher explained what she was doing. Because it was a large class - 19 - and there was so much standing around, some people became bored and began chatting amongst themselves and this made it difficult to always hear the teacher. All the food was delicious and the recipe book we were given will be well used but I just wished there had been more hands on. I feel so bad giving this a low rating, but for the price I felt the experience was a bit of a let down. It's a lovely way to spend a morning - beautiful surrounds and delicious food but I have to say all that standing around doing nothing is also hard on the legs. I wouldn't recommend this as a cooking class but I would definitely recommend buying Janet's book as the recipes are fantastic and come out deliciously and I would definitely recommend eating at the Casa Luna Restaurant.

Lots of fun - a must do in Ubud!. I took the Friday cooking class at Casa Luna. We learned to make chicken satay, peanut sauce, rujak salad, fried rice, pickled veggies, and fresh fruit cooked in coconut milk. All of the above was delicious. You can learn different dishes on different days of the week. They also offer a market class where you walk through the tradional market and learn what to buy. The Balinese have a really cool way of combining sweet, sour, salty, and spicy. It's a combo that we don't learn here in the US and unless you are taught which ingredients to use, you're at a loss. At least, I was. In addition, you learn about the benefits of each of those ingredients - lemon grass, 4 types of ginger, peppers, galangal, etc. The man who teaches is is very friendly, speaks great english, and he gives you little tidbits of Balinese culture throughout the class. It was only $35, included a meal at the end, and even a little glass of rice wine. You'll be given information on what tools you'd need for your own kitchen and where you are likely to find the asian ingredients back home in the US. The class is held on a beautiful shady, tropical plant surrounded patio with lots of fans, which is a nice respite in oppressive Indonesian heat! Pitchers of iced hibiscus tea (you'll learn how to make that too) are set on the table, along with ice cold water. I met a few Aussies and three Canadians. We had a great time chatting about our lives and travel adventures. It was a really lovely experience and I'm so glad I did it!

My favourite thing. This was a magic morning. We visited the local food market with a chef then back to the cooking school. Our teacher was amazing and one of the funniest ladies I have ever net. The cooking experience was brilliant and I am determined to reproduce the food for a banquet at home. Have to say the food we cooked was the best we had anywhere in Bali.

Great way to spend a morning!. I would have liked to have done the market tour, but as there was a special holiday the week I visited Ubud (Galungan) I only had the chance to do the cooking school on Friday morning which doesn't have the market visit. The lesson was very informative about ingredients and you get a little cookery book with the recipes to take away. I like the way you are given suggested substitutes f.or the ones you probably can't get at home. Most of the class is watching the teachers demonstrate rather than you cooking everything (as I did in Chang Mai, Thailand), but it was still a very enjoyable morning and I would recommend it. On the leaflet it said that the class finishes at 12.30, but actually that's when you sit down to eat. It's about 12.45 when you are actually finished. Food was delicious, especially the satay!

An interesting insight to cooking. We had great hopes for this cooking class, however we were a little disappointed. The begining of the class we listened to the instructor explain the ingredients (which was very informative and very interesting) then she went on to explain to us how wonderful her boss was at every moment she could (said boss - owner Janet) then came and took over the class, which I found to be disrespectful and her tone wasn't at all becoming for a 'teacher'. The majority of the remaining time was spent standing around waiting to take our turn at chopping, mixing or grinding. There was no 'cooking' in this cooking class :-( The end of the class was great in that we got to eat the food in which we "cooked", this was fantastic!!! Although given a recipe book which gives instructions on how to cook the dishes we were taught, there is a very slim chance I would be able to make these dishes at home.A lovely day in the beautiful surrounds of Ubud, however, I wouldn't be in too much of a hurry to go back.

Average cooking class. We started off our class with a trip to local market on foot.Our guide (although very nice) was extremely repetitive.He took us thru the dark,busy,lacking of "air" market for nearly two hours we had a repeat of the fruit,vege,& nuts that we had seen at previous stalls.At times I felt like I was going to faint from heat ( & lack of air ) with the extremely long excursion.Long walk back to Casa Luna school..beautiful environs with pool and "honeymooners" lying around it.Lush gardens...I felt the school unorganized for our arrival.The teacher lovely & very funny..though again repetitive...I really didn't learn anything new except her recipe for hibiscus tea was fantastic.There could have been more info ie pamphlets to take home..the food was nothing special.The day could be streamlined into a much more condensed version.Wouldnt go again.It was very basic info.

Not a real cooking class. We were so disappointed in this half day so called cooking class. We spent most of the class watching and waiting to take our turn to chop or mix. There were far too many people to share just a few chopping boards or mortar & pestles and the situation wasn't helped by most of the other participants who were very rude and disrespectful of the teacher, the others in the group and generally the whole experience. very disappointing to see fellow Australians behave in that way, particularly media personalities.The teacher was great and was so patient, but we came away from the experience without feeling confident we could reproduce the recipes at home.

Palm Sugar and Salt Tour. This sounds like such a strange itinerary, but it was a fantastic day. The took us into the mountains and showed in detail how the nectar is harvested and then turned into palm sugar. It was the same when we went to the sea to watch the salt - lots of work! We finished up with a great lunch at a warung filled with Balinese in their Sunday best.

Not hands on cooking, but good overview of ingredients. I took four days of cooking class here, i also stayed at the hotel. The environment and outside kitchen was great. The pro: they explained the ingredients in depth to us, price/quantity was good. The con: too many people in the class, no hands on, everyone just 'took a turn.' I personally thought the food was flavorless, despite all the fresh ingredients going into.

Cooking School With A Difference. There have been mixed reviews about this cooking school and our experience was also mixed. If it was called a cooking class, then visitors may be more informed as to what to expect. Firstly, Janet was not present and while the Balinese chef was bright and cheerful, we were expecting to meet Janet. Visitors really do not participate in the cooking of the dishes, except to prepare a few spices, as many of the ingredients are already prepared and the chef does the cooking. We were in a "class" of about 20 people and we ate the dishes at the end of the demonstration. I believe that it was a "fun" morning spent, but we came away not being satisfied that the main chef (Janet) did not even greet us, let alone prepare any food.For new travellers to Bali, it can be recommended, but treat it as light entertainment.

My best cooking class experience in Ubud. A cooking class is a great way to understand what you are eating in Bali, and why it tastes the way it does. I took one of Casa Luna's cooking classes more to understand Balinese food and what I like and don't like, than to replicate the dishes at home. I took a second class at another restaurant-and-cooking-school as well. Both classes were about 15 people, and surprisingly, about half were men, so men shouldn't feel intimidated about attending.Both classes were a mix of lecture, demonstration, participation, and meal. The Casa Luna class was informative about the ingredients and cooking techniques, the surrounding are charming, and the food was very flavorful--probably among the best I had in Bali during three weeks. Considering all this, the price is very reasonable. For me, the highlight of the class was a Balinese staff member going through the many fresh herbs used in the cuisine, as well as some of their uses in natural medicine. Several of the ingredients will be familiar to those who know other Southeast Asian cuisines, but there are some unique ingredients as well. Four types of ginger are used, for example. The richly colored native coconut sugar is unforgettable (If anyone reading this knows a mail order source in the U.S. for the first grade of gulab Bali, please let me know).There were more opportunities to participate in this class than in any of the 3-4 hour, introductory ethnic cooking classes that I have attended in the U.S. with a similar number of participants. Many of the cooking techniques--sauteeing, frying, steaming, simmering--are familiar to anyone who had done some cooking. With the guidance of Balinese cooking staff, several class members tried their hand at the more unfamiliar processes, such as grinding ingredients for basic curry paste on stone mortar and pestle, and making packets of food from banana leaves for steaming.I highly recommend the experience of a Casa Luna cooking class. And don't forget to visit their restaurants in Ubud--Casa Luna and Indus--to taste more of their wonderful food. If you like Thai food, as many people do, well-made Balinese food will become your new favorite!

Waste of money. I love to cook especially duck and was excited to do this course however it was pitched at the inexperienced cook and was very basic with limited hands on time. Wouldn't recommend not even for the meal, duck was just ok

Casa Luna Cooking School Palm Sugar and Sea Salt Tour. Having done a cooking class with Janet years ago, we decided on this visit to take the Palm Sugar and Sea Salt Tour. What a fascinating day it was - the palm sugar making process is absolutely amazing and the end product delicious! We were also given some to take some back home with us and can't wait to try cooking with it! The traditional salt harvesting is also an extraordinary thing to watch and you can buy freshly salt while you're there. An interesting and relaxing day out in the country - would definitely recommend it!

Yummy food though not very hands on.. I participated in the cooking class at Casa Luna last week and was impressed by the knowledge and skills of the presenters. I was not very hands on but I guess the food prep is the time consuming bit of any cooking and most of that was done by the staff. We learnt lots about the herbs and spices and the end result was a tasty meal.

An interesting insight into Bali culture. My friend really wanted to attend this class as her kids had given her the cookbook for Christmas. We went on a Tuesday so started at 8am for the market tour.The tour was very indepth (2 hours) and our guide Oleg knew everything there was to know about the market and the food, and he had the biggest smile I have ever seen! We learnt much about the roles of men and women in ceremonial cooking and making the Hindu offerings.The class itself involved lots of information about the various spices and various people took turns at the mortar & pestle, slicing up the food, or cooking in the wok while the rest of us looked on. Theere was a chance for everyone to have a turn at something if they wanted.We got to eat the food for lunch and it was very tasty.... plenty of vegetarian options but for someone like me who doesn't like even slightly spicy food, I stuck to the rice and mie goreng as the rest was a bit zingy for me. My friend however loved it.

Great way to spend the day. The food was fantastic, we tasted a lot, chopped a little, cooked a little and ate what was cooked. It was a lovely friendly atmosphere with very nice people who went along for the ride with us. I really enjoyed it and it was not expensive at all. The guide through the market was fantastic and that trip in itself was very educational. The only drawback was i wish i could have videod it in order to remember all that was said. I would like to do it again nxt time I am in Ubud.

An enjoyable day. A chef in Australia had recommended this course when we commenced a conversation while buying Janet's recent book. We were not disappointed as the ingredients were fresh and inviting and the teachers (including Janet after the introduction was began by one of her staff) were knowledgeable and patient. One of the "students" did question the amount of palm sugar used and Janet's response was something like "everything is good for you in Bali". I was also a little concerned about the high oil content and would have liked more advice on how to keep oil/sugar lower whilst maintaining flavour. We've been visiting many highly rated restaurants while in Bali for 2 weeks and we notice that they seem to use less oil/sugar/salt and still retain the flavour. There weren't many opportunities for hands on practice so that was a little disappointing too. The size of the group was good and we were inspired to return home and try more recipes from Janet's book. Many thanks to Janet and her staff!

Not what I expected. The cooking course is really kind of expensive - therefore I did expect to get a cooking class. but that is not what you get. you sit with 15 other People and Listen to a Lady explaining about different herbs in Bali - afterwards she starts cooking. It is like a cooking show you can watch in TV. They should definitely tell in advance! that is really not what one expects from a cooking class!!!!!

fantastic day in ubud. we really enjoyed our market tour and cooking at casa luna cooking school.The hosts were excellent, genuine funny people who loved their jobs.Highly recommend it - the foood was so yummy

The best lunch (and experience) in Ubud. This class was truly outstanding and one of my absolute favorite experience from my entire 2 weeks in Bali. Janet is a highly skilled instructor with so much knowledge to share. You get lots of hands on action with the spices and gorgeous fresh ingredients and at the end, one of the best meals you'll have on the island. Nasi Campur does not get any better, guaranteed. Plus, you'll meet lots of great people from around the world. Don't forget to have a look at Janet's books. I bought Fragrant Rice and she was kind enough to sign with a lovely personal message. I devoured it during the next few days on the beach and have to say it really made my time in Bali that much better. Thanks Janet and your wonderful staff. We'll be back!

A top experience in Bali for sure!. This class was truly outstanding and one of my absolute favorite experience from my entire 2 weeks in Bali. Janet is a highly skilled instructor with so much knowledge to share. You get lots of hands on action with the spices and gorgeous fresh ingredients and at the end, one of the best meals you'll have on the island. Nasi Campur does not get any better, guaranteed. Plus, you'll meet lots of great people from around the world. Don't forget to have a look at Janet's books. I bought Fragrant Rice and she was kind enough to sign with a lovely personal message. I devoured it during the next few days on the beach and have to say it really made my time in Bali that much better. Thanks Janet and your wonderful staff. We'll be back!

great cooking School in Ubud. My wife & I attended the Casa Luna Cooking School and it was perfect. First we went to the food market the morning before and we were shown all the different ingredients for sale as well as all the different (very sharp) knifes used for Balinese cooking. As for the cooking event it was a well balanced combination of demonstrations and practice, especially how to grind properly on a flat volcano rock grinder. And all this in a relaxed atmosphere and full of humour from the lady chef in charge. We highly recommend this event to all serious foodies!

Cooking school in Ubud, Bali. I loved participating in one of the cooking classes here. Everything was so organised. We met, had a tour of local market, returned to cooking school for morning tea which was scrumptious, learned how to make hibiscus drink, then helped cook up a feast which we ate, just lovely!

Cooking demonstation. Spent the morning at Casa Luna, the two ladies that were doing the demonstation were very informative and entertaining. The explained the most popular herbs used and what are available in Australia. The grounds of the school are luxurious, would have loved to have stayed there.

Excellent Experience. I spent an extra week in Ubud expressly to attend this cooking school and am delighted I did. In all, I did 5 classes (Sunday (2 classes) thru Wednesday). I was prepared to do the Thursday class, but was advised it was really a repeat of what I had learned already and staff gave me the recipes.About 75% of the class is demonstration - first going over all the spices needed for the dishes that would be prepared, then watching the actual cooking. We participated by slicing, dicing, chopping, blending, crushing, peeling and eating. In effect, participants get a 5 course lunch along with the class.Janet De Neefe (owner) did not teach the week I was there, but classes were handled wonderfully by Udai (main teacher), Oleg (main assistant and guide for the Sunday Salt/Sugar tour and the Tuesday Market Tour), Pandi (assistant and driver for the Sunday tour and helper for the Market Tour) and Wilma. There cannot be a better dream team for teaching Balinese cooking anywhere.If you stay on-property, at Honeymoon Cottages (same owner), you can have a 10% discount on classes. If attending in high season (July and August), book early as there is a maximum of 16 participants.

Casa Luna Cooking School. Had a fabulous time at the cooking class beginning with a market tour followed by instruction with Yude who was just delightful. The tips we learned were helpful and you could participate as much or as little as you liked. Eating the delicious food the group had a hand in preparing was a treat! Highly recommended.

Great Job!. Recently I attended a Thursday cooking class through Casa de Luna in Ubud, Bali. The class began with a substantial visit to the local market. Our instructor explained in detail various foods and spices. The instructor was knowledgeable and funny. The visit was followed by the cooking class held at one of the Casa de Luna lodging sites. We gathered in a lovely demo space. We started off with a delicious mid-morning breakfast. Our cooking instructor was terrific. Again she was knowledgeable and funny. The various foods were prepared in collaboration with the class who joined in with chopping and stirring. This was followed with a sumptious lunch meal. All in all, I highly recommend attending one of these weekly classes. I had a great time. And I left with a smashing Casa de Luna cooking apron.

Smoked duck - mouth watering but not really a lesson more a demo. We were very excited to come to this renowned cooking class... a bit nervous after reading some TA reviews - & most of them were right. Our booking started with being quoted various prices, then being sent to 2 different locations. Once in the class we struggled through lights on, then lights off... poor staff - but the lovely teacher soldiered on! We heard about every herb, spice & nut in the dish, in detail which was interesting but did little of the cooking ourselves - just a bit of prep. Disappointing when the classes are the most expensive in Ubud. We had the lovely Casa Luna aprons on - only to be told we had to give them back - no momento's for a $50-$60 "lesson".

Great day - fab food experience. After a tour of the market we settled in for a great morning. Making spice pastes and understanding the ingredients was terrific. The staff were friendly and knowledgeable and eveyone got involved. The best thing was we got to eat all the yummy food at the end of the demonstration with other attendees from many different countries. We enjoyed it so much we booked in for a second day! Highly recommended

Loved it!. Our first time to Bali & stayed at Honeymoon Guesthouse so could not miss out on the cooking school. Had booked Tuesday as Janet teaches Mon & Tues only but Janet was away in Melbourne so missed her. The market tour was excellent and got some great tips from Oleg on a whole lot of local knowledge & how not to get scammed. The cooking class was demonstration which suited us fine. We enjoyed grinding chilies and peeling eggplant and stirring tempeh curry. Staff were gracious and had great sense of humor. Loved eating the dishes we made & enjoyed learning about Balinese food. Got to meet other visitors to Ubud & loved the recipe book to take home so I can cook up a Balinese Banquet at home.

So much fun!. We took a class at Casa Luna Cooking School while on our honeymoon in Bali. It was a fantastic experience! My husband and I both enjoy cooking, but had never tried anything Indonesian in the kitchen before this adventure and it was so well worth it. Janet and the staff were so knowledgeable and friendly. And the meal we prepared was hands down one of the best meals we had our entire time in Bali. I really enjoyed that the beginning of the class is spent discussing the local ingredients - seeing, touching, feeling, smelling the items that will be used to make your meal. It was a wonderful experience and although we didn't have enough time to make it over to Janet's restaurant, Casa Luna, we hope to get back to Bali again one day and it's definitely on the list!

Didn't quite meet expectations. While the food at Casa Luna is lovely, the cooking school is more of a demonstration event . The staff are friendly and informative, but not being able to cook the dishes personally detracted from the learning experience. I was also disappointed by the school admin. I attended on a Tuesday, but there wasn't a market tour becasue of an upcoming festival - I knew this in advance & was fine with it. But when I called the day before to check the start time, the staff said to come at the usual hour (8am). The class actually started at 9:30. Getting up and there an hour and a half early wasn't ideal, and we didn't get an apology for the timing mix up either.

Slightly disappointing. I attended a cooking class/demonstration on a Wednesday morning in early November. I'd picked up Janet's book in town and read it so was hopeful to have her sign it but she wasn't available. The staff were very pleasant but did most of the cooking. There were only two cooking stations so when we were encouraged to help out everyone (15 in the class) took turns. Other places I've taken cooking classes we started at the market (which they do here just twice a week), the classes were smaller (5-8), and each person had a cooking station where we prepared the food we would actually eat. It was much more of a learning experience than this. The lunch the staff prepared was delicious and the information they shared was interesting. The conversation with friendly tourists sitting near me from the UK and US was very pleasant. Since there was time to chat while the staff cooked it turned out the side conversations were a highlight of the class, not what I'd expected based on my previous experience with cooking classes elsewhere. All in all it was a pleasant morning but perhaps should be advertised as a cooking demonstration to eliminate higher expectations.

Good for Eating, Not for Learning. A bit let down by this one as it's a pricy thing to do for Ubud. Staff taught, no Janet in sight and the staff did almost all of the cooking. The food however was fabulous and I learned that I like the local rice wine:)

Casa Luna Cooking School. I attending Casa Luna Cooking School on Monday and Tuesday 2 weeks ago. It was very good and informative. Not a lot of hands on work. Janet de Neefe usually only teaches 2 classes a week on Monday and Tuesday. The other days her staff teach.

One for the taste One for good luck. Sorry for the delay !
Excellent experience, the family was so friendly, we have lot of fun. We were lucky because we have a private cooking class me and my partner.
All the dishes were delicious, we learn so much about cooking and the balinese culture during the day.
Thank you so much
Vincent and Pamela

The best cooking class in Bali!. This was arguably the best 5 hours of my time in Ubud. The cooking class was unbelievably fun, the dishes were outstanding and easy, and the entire atmosphere was excellent. It was worth every penny! I had such a great time and hope my dishes turn out as excellent as they did yesterday! Thanks so much!

"A hands-on cooking experience". Wonderful setting right next to our Bidadari Retreat. Excellent guided tour of the produce market and then transported to the cooking class venue where we were shown a multitude of Balinese traditional dishes in a Balinese family home. Well set up with individual cooking stations and seating in a private setting. Would thoroughly recommend this as part of your trip to Ubud.

Home Cooking In Bali. Having sampled the delights of cooking in a Moroccan kitchen in June, my recent trip to Bali could only be enhanced by a similar experience. I love South East Asia, the people, the culture, the climate all fascinate me. Above all I love the food with its light, citrus and herby flavours and an emphasis on ginger, galangal, tamarind, coconut and lemon grass. The region has also embraced many outside influences in terms of its cuisine. From the filled French baguettes of Vietnam to Indian influenced curries and spicing from Persia. Protein choices include fish, chicken and tofu with beef and pork served mainly for the tourist market .Prior to departure I trawelled the internet looking for an authentic Balinese cookery class and found the Jambangan Bali Cooking class. What appealed to me about this school compared with the others I found was that they take you a Balinese market prior to class and introduce to the ingredients you will be using. Also that it takes place in the home of the school’s owner, Rakesh.On the appointed day we were picked up at our hotel at 9.30am by Rakesh and driven to the market. During the journey we passed many paddy fields and he explained that each home owns their own field, where they grow the rice for the family. The fields will produce two crops per year with a yield of about 100kg of rice. The crop takes five months to plant, grow and harveste, then in the fallow month the family will put their ducks into the fields to eat the insects and fertilise the ground. I asked Rakesh how many grains of rice an average plant will produce and was surprised to find it was only between 10 and 15. Traditionally the Balinese eat rice with every meal, even breakfast. It is their staple food.On arrival at the market we met some of our fellow classmates; a jolly bunch hailing from all over the globe. Rakesh’s cousin, Capung, himself a chef showed us around the market stalls and explained what the various goods were on show. Capung means dragonfly in Balinese and the name suited him, as he darted about and made us smile.After the market, we were driven to the house where we were welcomed with a cool drink and Rakesh explained the layout of a traditional Balinese compound. There isn’t one house in the complex but four and each has a different purpose. In the south is the wedding house, which the family use for eating and celebrations. In the East is the honeymoon house, where the newly weds start their married life. To the North is the children’s house and to the west is the kitchen house. There is also a temple, usually built before the houses and the rice house to store the family’s food supply. At this point another group of pupils arrived, a gaggle of elderly Australian ladies who were travelling together. Once everyone had settled we were introduced to the lady who was going to be our teacher for the day. Our first task was to weave an offerings basket, which we did to varying levels of success and then fill them with flowers, in order to bring success to our endeavours in the kitchen. The kitchens themselves were open air, although with a roof and the lady went through dishes we were going to cook.Vegetable Soup - vegetables and mushrooms in a chicken brothSate Empol - traditional minced chicken kebabs with a peanut satay sauceLawar Bali – an Indonesian salad Gado-Gado – an Indonesian salad of steamed vegetables, tofu, hard-boiled eggs served with a peanut sauce.Tempe Manis – Fried soya bean curd in a sweet and sour sauce. Ayum Curry – This is nothing like an Indian curry. It is much more delicate and fragrant than that.Tum Ayum – A popular Balinese dish of chicken steamed with spices and coconut in banana leaves and finished on the barbeque. This dish is often made with fish too. Banana and Jack Fruit with a caramel sauce. – The fruit is poached in water, sugar and cornstarch and served with a palm sugar caramel sauce. We were soon split in to teams and put to work slicing, chopping, and mixing, using traditional methods, with not an electrical gadget in sight. The chicken was put into two big stone mortars on the floor and then pounded within an inch of its life with two 6-foot long wooden pestles. We were certainly working up an appetite. Between us we created the base of a lot of Balinese cuisine, Basic Yellow Sauce, (or Gede Bumbu Kuning). It is a mix of shallots, garlic, turmeric roots, candlenuts, galangal, ginger, chillies, lemongrass, spices and palm sugar and it is fragrant and flavoursome.The first dish to be finished was the soup and once dished up we were invited to sit at the large communal table in the wedding house and enjoy it together. It was light and delicious and we soon got to know our fellow diners, who included natives of Korea, Japan, Germany, Denmark and a Geordie lass.Then it was back to the kitchen to prepare our main and dessert dishes. Everyone was encouraged to get involved, taking it in turns to cook and add ingredients. The Sate Empol kebabs were shaped from balls of the chicken mix on to flat bamboo sticks and then cooked on a BBQ over smoldering coconut shells. The Balinese certainly don’t believe in waste, using the whole of the palm tree and its fruit in one form or another.Again we sat at the communal table and enjoyed our feast, with a cold Bintang beer and a feeling of self-satisfaction that we were all now authentic Balinese cooks.After the meal was finished and with no washing up to do Rakesh drove us back to our hotel. This fabulous, fun-packed, educational day, with transport and a full belly, cost us the grand sum of £22. An absolute bargain and the best day out of our trip.
Must do ! . This class was a pure delight what a beautiful family welcoming you into their home add this your must do list for Ubud. Wishing you many more classes and hope to be back with my family

A great way to enjoy Balinese culture!. My wife and I decided to take a cooking class recommended by our honeymoon driver and we were very happy with this activity!After picking you up at your hotel, they take you to a market where you take a quick tour of what ingredients you'll be cooking for each of your dishes. It was interesting to see how people buy their ingredients in an open market instead of grocery store.After the tour we were taken to a house that was setup as the cooking class. I liked the idea of them using their actual house as the activity spot because it helped add to the Balinese environment and true home cooked meal. The main teacher was so cheerful and upbeat it actually made the cooking part fun. They show you the true Balinese way of cooking without blenders and machines. Plus it was cool to see how certain things are made from scratch as opposed to buying it ready made in a grocery store. It did take a few hours to cook all the dishes but if you look at my attached photos there were a lot! In all, the food ended up tasting great! So many dishes and flavors it really felt like a home cooked meal. Would 100% recommend this to all couples and even the singles because it is fun, culturally fulfilling and the food was amazing!!

Great cooking class!. This was a fantastic cooking class. The family were very friendly and inviting. Other classes I looked at you didn't cook and taste your own food but here you do. They also provide water throughout and you get a great insight into Bali culture. You also receive the recipes so you can make it at home. Would recommend this place. They also pick you up and drop you back off at your hotel and the driver arrived on time.
Lets go makan. It was a very nice class, go for the basic yellow sauce (and all other things delicious)! And had a bit information about balinese houses as well

Perfect cooking class!. We had the cooking class this afternoon. It was really good! The event already started after we were picking up at the hotel. The driver (Rakesh) picked us up and started telling nice information. He brought us to the location which was very nice, at their private house. His sister and cousin (very friendly and funny) learned how to cook. I had a special request and wanted to make Soto Ayam instead of vegetarian food, that was no problem and we cooked that. So they are flexible as well. Definitely recommend this place!

Do not leave Ubud without doing this!. We ate so well our whole Bali trip, but this was the best food we had by far.We went as a group of four and teamed up with 8 others to make a group of 12. The beautiful Balinese house was made to fee like we were relatives visiting our Balinese family by the lovely hosts. The food we made as a team was authentic and flavoursome, but most important was the attention to details.Why this class is great...Obviously, you learn amazing recipes but also:We learnt about the food production, such as making your own coconut oil. We were made to be food safe, so we were given many utensils, aprons, gloves and instructions in English.Half of our party was vegetarian, and this was catered for with a vegan menu that ran alongside the meat menu. Yes, that's right we learnt two kind of meals, and I've never tasted vegan food that was so delicious.We had our morning class on Kuningan, a Holy holiday for the Hindu people of Bali. The cooking class still ran, and the family came back from the ceremony halfway through the class. This meant we were able to discuss Balinese culture and see the beautiful sarong attire that everyone wears during this day. The hosts were great about this, and made us feel welcome to talk with them about the day.During the whole class bottled water is supplied so you. Stay hydrated in the hot Bali weather! Also the weather is not a factor- it's all undercover in a big tiled open air kitchen.Thank you Nyoman and family for a lovely morning, great memories and delicious recipes!

Great cooking experience. I really enjoyed myself at this cooking class, but i feel like I haven't done much... In the end, I don't think I can replicate the recipes back home based on what I did, but maybe with the written recipes I'll get close.

Awsome. My Husband, Daughter and her Boyfriend went here in May 2016. My Husband and I have been going to Bali for many years and been to many cooking classes, we really enjoyed this class as it is very friendly and family run. they made us feel so welcome and the cooking is so easy and the recipe that they gave us when we finished was easy to read and we found most of the ingredients at home in Australia. We will be back thank you for a great time. Sandy

delicious fun. done 2 cooking classes and this was the better of the 2. The hostess was warn and welcoming. Her English was very good. it was in a home atmosphere but still open to the outside. Hand hygiene was stressed and students washed hands before preparing food and after handling raw meat and gloves were provided when handling hot chilli. We did a bit of cooking and then sat down and ate the food prepared with the other students in a separate dining area and then a bit more cooking...the pace was relaxed and fun. All the food was delicious and the recipe book to take home was great

Amazing experience -best food we had in Indonesia. We decided to sign up for the evening cooking class one day in advance. The next day we were picked up from our hostel in Ubud on time (which was a first for us in Bali ;)). When we arrived at the house we were welcomed very warmly by our cooking instructors. It is a family business so every family member has a different task. It turned out that we were the only two who signed up for the evening so we received a private cooking lesson. The women were very friendly and explained everything very well. The food was extremely tasteful, it turned out to be the best food we had during the whole three weeks in Indonesia!! Besides the cooking we learned also a lot about the Balinese culture. I would certainly recommend this cooking class and hope you will have a really nice and tasteful experience too. Last but not least, at the end of the evening you get a booklet with recipes of all the food you have made..so you can try to make the delish food once you return back home :)

Thoroughly recommended - Great Afternoon with a friendly local family.. A must to-do in Ubud.We phoned them in the morning and we were collected at the arranged time from our hotel.We were the only people cooking that afternoon so my wife, teenage daughter and myself were fully looked after. Its about 20 minutes from the centre of Ubud and when we got there we had a coconut drink waiting for us and then given a tour of the grounds by the very friendly family.After that we started preparing the various meals. You needn't take notes as they give you and English version of the recipes later. You can get all the ingredients at home but you will need to visit Asian and Indian supermarkets. We made the base genep (yellow) sauce and had fun with Balinese Kenwood Chef.Once the genep was made we cooked the following meals: a spicy clear vegetable soup, sate empol (cooked over burning coconut shells), steamed fish in banana leaves, chicken curry , tempeh manis, gado-gado , lawar bali and finally the desert Kolak Ubi.We were totally full after eating all that and after about 4 hours we were taken back to our hotel in Ubud.

Simply Fantastic... Not to be missed. A great way to meet new people whilst having fun preparing and cooking Balinese dishes. We were met at our resort location by the driver at 09:00 prompt. We picked up some other participants en route to a market a short drive away.Our friendly guide took us through various vegetables and spices that we would be using for our culinary experience later in the morning.This was not a tourists market but one used by the locals.He guided us through the marked and explained the different spices used in balinese cuisine, along with different fruits and vegetables. After the market we were taken to the Balinese home for the cooking class. We learnt about balinese culture, religion and family traditions and also had an opportunity to as many questions. Then to the food. What can I say except you really need to experience this for yourself. Simply wonderful. We spent the next few hours preparing, cooking, and tasting Balinese traditional cuisine. I would recommend Jambangan Bali Cooking Class to everyone who travels to Ubud... Not to be missed!

Unique experience . We arranged this cooking class through our villa which was a short walk away. It was lovely to find out about the traditional house before starting the class with a small group. The class was well organised and explained clearly. The food was enjoyed gradually throughout the evening and was delicious. It was a nice touch to receive a copy of the recipes to try at home.

Great experience, all were satisfied!. We went as a group of 6 adults (3 couples) and the cooking skills and experience were quite stretched among us. Well we all contributed and learned many things and the results were delicious and filling ;-)

Last morning in Bali . This was a great way to say goodbye to Bali! My kids and I had wonderful time! This family is very organized and prepared. We had a great market tour and explanation of family life in the Balinese culture. The cooking class was great. We participated in every step and were allowed to sit and enjoy what we created. All people can participate, even the children. My kids were encouraged to help and the family seemed genuinely delighted they were there. Even though this family hold this cooking class everyday, they made us feel special. They understand that it is new and exciting to us and they make it fun. We learned a lot and the food was great!! We each had our favorites.

Fantastic. We chose to do the afternoon class because we taught it would be nice to have dinner with the food we cooked. Transport was included so we were picked up at our hotel at 3pm. First we went to a coffee plantation, it was fun to see but I wouldn't have missed it if we didn't go, but maybe that's just because i had already been to one previously. If you take the morning class you'll go to a good market which has much more to do with the cooking class.) The cooking class is held at a traditional Balinese family home, so when we arrived we got some information about these traditional houses first, which was really interesting because I'd never heard it before. The women who helped us with the cooking were also super friendly, and spoke English really well. They worked like a well-oiled machine. We needed a little more help than usual because we were only with the two of us. The food was delicious and the staff super friendly. It was way too much food, so it's a shame that we had to throw it away :(They gave us all the recipes printed on paper so we could make it at home. Can't wait!! Definitely recommend to do this during your holiday, it's suitable for friends, family, couples and elderly.

Loved it. Me and my boyfriend did this cooking class today and we really liked it! We were in a group of 6, which was perfect. We were picked up from our hotel and then went to the market. It was nice to see all the herbs, vegetables and other ingredients. After a lovely trip through the rice fields we were welcomed with a fresh cocunut. The star of our course was Made. She was a energetic woman and, more important, she speaks really good English and she explained everything very well. She was also very funny: just put one table spoon of sugar and one for good luck ;)The lunch after we had was great, especially the tempeh kecap! We would recommend this cooking class to anyone!

Great Ambience with Authentic Food. Went there to eat late at night (considerably late for Ubud, around 8pm). Nice cozy setting with soothing music. We are vegetarian so just went for the veggie stuff which was good. Tips:- highly recommend the fried banana skewers with peanut butter. - no kids menu

Authentic Balinese experience. Rakesh and his family were very welcoming and walked us through a fun filled morning of cooking. Everything was organized very well from the market visit all the way up until dessert. Great experience and wonderful family! Highly recommend booking your cooking class through Jambangan where they'll "put you to work"

Well Organized and Relaxing. The booking over the Internet was responsive and easy. We were a party of 7 (including two children). Rakesh picked us up in the morning on time, and the first stop was to the local market, not the touristy market but the real deal where the locals go. In fact, we were the only foreign visitors there. The next stop was a coffee plantation where we get to see the civet cats and tasted a variety of flavoured coffee. There was no high-pressure selling. The cooking class was conducted in Rakesh family house, very beautiful and tranquil, and just about 15 mins drive from Ubud centre. Another two guests joined us, but the class was well organized such that all 9 of us, including the children, get to do the cutting and cooking. They spoke English comprehensibly well. The class ended with dishes we cooked, which was delicious and plentiful. Lunch ended at about 2pm. Highly recommended for a pleasant, un-rushed cooking experience with a completely authentic flavour, from the recipe to the house to the market.

Highly recommended!. We chose this class based on the tripadvisor reviews and really enjoyed it. We did the afternoon class and were picked up from our hotel at 3pm by Rakesh. He drove us to his family home where we were welcomed with a drink and an explanation of the layout of a typical Balinese family compound.We were a group of 4 and joined 6 others in the class. Parts of the cooking process had been prepared in advance but we worked in groups to prepare a number of dishes whilst being guided along - chicken curry, vegetable soup, gado gado, chicken satay etc We finished the class at 6:30pm and were dropped back to our hotel after. The price was 350,000 IDR per person.Really enjoyed making and eating authentic Balinese dishes (more authentic than the food in central Ubud which caters for the tourist) and Rakesh's family were very kind and welcoming. Highly recommended whilst staying in Ubud!

Extremely well organised but very large group. A great way to spend a morning in Ubud. I learned a lot and the food tasted delicious. There were 14 people in our group so limited opportunities to cook though. I imagine a group of 8 would make this an exceptional experience

Family highlight! Great experience!. Jambangan cooking school was an awesome overall experience. We went with our two kids, ages 11 and 14. We were picked up on time from our villa. The trip to the market in the nearby town was an experience onto itself, it is a real working village market that your guide expertly winds you through. The sights, sounds, smells... really was a blast. Each ingredient we would later used was explained as we toured by our guide. After our time there, we were shuttled back to their home, and we are immediately "put to work" in the kitchen prepping food. We prepared around 8 courses and a dessert. Every ingredient was prepped by us, under their instruction. We also cooked everything ourselves, tasting as we went. Have to say, "our" meal was one of the best we had in Bali, and we really learned the techniques to make these dishes at home. My son even learned how to carve a crab out of a cucumber!The staff was friendly and efficient, always there to help guide you but making sure you did it yourself. The kids had a blast and it was an excellent family adventure. Reasonably priced for the meal and the experience. Definitely try to do the morning market tour option, as that really added to the experience. Would highly recommend.

Very good experience. Nice visit to the market, stop on the way to see rice fields since people asked for it, and then visit of a coffee plantation.The cooking lesson was given by a very friendly staff, and the food delicious. You can chose a vegetarian menu if needed which I find great. This was a great way to discover more about balinese culture.

Balinese home cookin'. We did an afternoon cookery class at Jambangan Bali, we were collected from our hotel at 3pm and dropped back at 6.30pm. Unlike the morning class, this does not include a trip to the market but we did not mind about that. First we were toured around the traditional Balinese house learning about the different buildings and family temple before making an offering to the gods before we began cooking. We were taught how to make 8 Balinese dishes in total using all fresh ingredients and a number of spices. We made both a yellow sauce and peanut sauce to accompany various dishes and the whole class was very fun and enjoyable whilst also informative and interesting.All of the staff were so friendly and if you bring your camera they will take some photos for you whilst you are cooking. The food itself was delicious and we were very full by the end of the class. The afternoon classes seem quieter than the morning, with only 4 people in our session. We really liked this as it felt very intimate and we could have a go at everything.
